text-decoration-color: #EEE; opacity: 1; border: 1px solid #201F1A; border-radius: 1px; z-index: -1; outline: 1px solid #FFFFFF; } .overlay_window_content p { color: #FFFFFF; } .description_window_small{ height: 50%; } `; document.head.appendChild(style); } } advisorFeedback(); // Variables for 2024: Divided States of America // Attorney General, or AG var ag = 'null'; // Speaker of the House, or Speaker window.speaker = 'Pelosi'; Read About Vice President Kamala Harris:

  • Name: ${pot_run_mat[0].fields.first_name} ${pot_run_mat[0].fields.last_name}
  • Party: ${pot_run_mat[0].fields.party}
  • Home State: ${pot_run_mat[0].fields.state}
${pot_run_mat[0].fields.description_as_running_mate}

` let vp_screen = document.createElement("div"); vp_screen.classList.add("inner_window_w_desc"); vp_screen.id = "inner_window_4"; vp_screen.innerHTML = vp_html; changeGameDisp(true); gameWindow.appendChild(vp_screen); // now we make the stuff do stuff! $("#running_mate_id").change((_e)=>{ _e.preventDefault() let value = Number($("#running_mate_id").val()); let i = potential_running_mate_pks.findIndex(f=>f === value); let screen_html = `
  • Name: ${pot_run_mat[i].fields.first_name} ${pot_run_mat[i].fields.last_name}
  • Party: ${pot_run_mat[i].fields.party}
  • Home State: ${pot_run_mat[i].fields.state}
${pot_run_mat[i].fields.description_as_running_mate}
` $("#running_mate_description_window").html(screen_html); }); // VP selected! $("#running_mate_id_button").click((_e)=>{ _e.preventDefault(); let value = Number($("#running_mate_id").val()); let i = potential_running_mate_pks.findIndex(f=>f === value); if ($("#campaign_sign")[0]) { $("#campaign_sign").html(`

${e.candidate_last_name}

${e.running_mate_last_name}

`); } $("#inner_window_4").remove(); changeGameDisp(false); }) } // Regular VP Switcher e.vpSwitcher = () => { let potential_running_mate_pks = e.running_mate_json.filter(f=>f.fields.candidate == e.candidate_id).map(f=>f.fields.running_mate); let pot_run_mat = potential_running_mate_pks.map(f=>e.candidate_json.find(_f=>_f.pk===f)); let running_mate_options = ``; pot_run_mat.forEach(f=> { running_mate_options += `\n` }); let vp_html = `

  • Party: ${pot_run_mat[0].fields.party}
  • Home State: ${pot_run_mat[0].fields.state}
${pot_run_mat[0].fields.description_as_running_mate}

` let vp_screen = document.createElement("div"); vp_screen.classList.add("inner_window_w_desc"); vp_screen.id = "inner_window_4"; vp_screen.innerHTML = vp_html; changeGameDisp(true); gameWindow.appendChild(vp_screen); // now we make the stuff do stuff! $("#running_mate_id").change((_e)=>{ _e.preventDefault() let value = Number($("#running_mate_id").val()); let i = potential_running_mate_pks.findIndex(f=>f === value); let screen_html = `

// Options for the observer (which mutations to observe) const windowsAdvisorConfig = { attributes: true, childList: true, subtree: true }; // Callback function to execute when mutations are observed const callback = (mutationList, observer) => { visitWindow = document.getElementsByClassName("overlay_window")[0]; if(visitWindow == null || visitWindow.classList.contains("done")) { return; } visitWindow.classList.add("done"); visitWindow.classList.add("window"); let titleBar = visitWindow.querySelector("h3"); titleBar.classList.add("title-bar"); titleBar.classList.add("title-bar-text") titleBar.style.paddingLeft = "3px"; }; class Song { constructor(title, artist, coverLink, audioLink) { this.title = title; this.artist = artist; this.coverLink = coverLink; this.audioLink = audioLink; } getTitle() { return this.title; } getArtist() { return this.artist; } getCoverLink() { return this.coverLink; } getAudioLink() { return this.audioLink; } } class Playlist { constructor() { this.songs = []; this.currentSongIndex = 0; } addSong(song) { this.songs.push(song); } getCurrentSong() { return this.songs[this.currentSongIndex]; } playNext() { this.currentSongIndex = (this.currentSongIndex + 1) % this.songs.length; } playPrevious() { this.currentSongIndex = (this.currentSongIndex - 1 + this.songs.length) % this.songs.length; } } window.Playlist=Playlist window.Song=Song function changePlaylist(newPlaylist) { playlist = newPlaylist; playlist.currentSongIndex = 0; updateUI(playlist); const audio = document.getElementById("audio"); audio.src = playlist.getCurrentSong().audioLink; audio.play(); } window.changePlaylist=changePlaylist function updateUI(playlist) { const currentSong = playlist.getCurrentSong(); var player = document.getElementById("player"); player.querySelector("#cover").src = currentSong.getCoverLink(); player.querySelector("#title").textContent = currentSong.getTitle(); player.querySelector("#artist").textContent = currentSong.getArtist(); audio.currentTime = seekTime; }); const audio = document.createElement("audio"); audio.id = "audio"; audio.src = playlist.getCurrentSong().audioLink; audio.volume = 1/9; audio.addEventListener("timeupdate", updateProgressBar); "; if (e.page > 0) { html += `` } if (e.page < e.pages.length - 1) { html += `` } for (i in e.executable) { if (e.executable[i][0] == e.page) { e.executable[i][1](); } } if (e.image == true) setTimeout(()=>{ candImg = $(".person_image")[0] if (candImg) { candImg.remove() console.log("TRYING"); $("#final_results_description")[0].style = ` text-align:left; width: 72%; height:71%; display: block; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto; overflow: auto; ` console.log("RESULTS UPDATED"); } }, 10) else if (e.image) setTimeout(()=>{ candImg = $(".person_image")[0]; if (candImg) { candImg.src = e.image; console.log("TRYING"); $("#final_results_description")[0].style = ` text-align:left; width: 72%; height:71%; display: block; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto; overflow: auto; ` console.log("RESULTS UPDATED"); } }, 10) return html; } endingConstructor = (a = 1) => { $("#final_results_description")[0].innerHTML = construct(a); } // ENDINGS -- this is slightly more reliable than the ending code method e.multiple_endings = true; e.header = "

Finnegan's Wake

Within the fraying body of an octogenarian irishman lay an addled mind alight with rapture.

It was inconceivable. The oval office, already rapt in a thin silence in anticipation of oblivion at the hands of the enemy now found itself drowning in it as the night unfolded. The results which trickled onto the small television screen tucked neat and obscure in the corner of the room as if to shelter the president from his oncoming annihilation had betrayed the premonitions of the President's inner circle. They did not speak. They could not speak. Even the pundits which briefly flashed onto the display between ballot drops remained mum or offered up unconvincing reassurances of a Blue Mirage which only grew louder as the magnitude of the victory they were witnessing became apparent. It was impossible. Unfathomable, even. Though more divided than ever, the American people seemed united by a single, unshakable conviction that this outcome was impossible.

All except one. The president watched as his loyalists stilled, one by one, as what they were witnessing finally became too much to deny. Their faces had turned ashen white. Their gazes had been firmly affixed earthwards to avoid his own, but it did not phase him. The intransigence of his underlings had meant nothing, their incompetence laid bare as the levy broke and states began being called. When Blitzer, that rodent, murmured something about Kentucky being still too close to call it all finally began clicking into place.

The mainstream media was quick to change its tune and yet eons too late. FOX published a hailstorm of quickly-rescinded pre-written pre-scheduled eulogies alongside hastily scribbled together reports of unexpected strength in deep-red states which quickly morphed into descriptions of a massacre. Senator Vance mounted the stage in the moments before the first poll closures to deliver a resounding declaration of victory, of war against the liberal establishment. He begins sliding off script as his staffers issue him increasingly concerning reports of devastating swings across Appalachia as the results pour in over the first five minutes, begins sliding into accusations of voter fraud by ten. The tears begin flowing by minute fifteen, and his mascara starts running down his ruddy cheeks.

CNN scrambles to rework its programming as the night ticks on. The next Carter becomes the next Truman, then the next Obama, then the next Roosevelt. They say Joe Biden is paralysed, his body broken. They say Joe Biden is a sphinx; quiet, secretive. They say Joe Biden is Amtrak Joe, Scranton boy, hero of the working man. They say Joe Biden is a dead man walking come alive, another echo of his predecessor's once-certain defeat in 1936. They say Joe Biden is That Man In The White House once more. They say Joseph Robinette Biden is nothing less than another FDR.

Perhaps he is. Perhaps he is more.

His gaze transits the Oval Office, daring the small gaggle of supposed associates to break their monklike silence and recognise the victory unfolding before them. He knows what is to be done. He alone knows the day and the hour and the minute and the second of the coming of man, and he knows that it is now. He knows there shall be one in the bed and one in the field and one of two women grinding grain in the mill. His enemies have shown their faces now, and he knows he shall cut them asunder. He knows there will be weeping and the gnashing of the teeth, and he awaits it with glee. Nothing can stop them now.

...

And within the fraying body of the irish octogenarian... lay a mind... convinced that it was God.

`) //e.image = "" e.executable.push([0, (() => {e.image = e.image = 'https://itsastronomical.com/assets/2024/endings/bidenfdr.png'})]) } else if (quickstats[0] >= 350 && campaignTrail_temp.candidate_json[0]["fields"].last_name == "Biden") { e.pages.push(`

Democracy Defended, Liberty Restored

Biden sat beside Jill quietly, eyes affixed to the television. Early returns never revealed much. Safe states are called, the blue mirage begins pouring in from urban centers across the country. Biden had seen this play out for decades. He folded his hands in his lap and waited. People filtered in and out of the room, and still he waited. A handful of promising signs - Texas, Florida, Ohio, all too close to call. But the rural vote would trickle in, and the red mirage would start to seep into the projections. Biden was confident it would all balance out in his favor, but he braced himself for that inevitable dip, for that surge of rural voters that would put them in dire straits for a few hours. He knew the drill.

The minutes ticked on, the rural vote was coming in, but the blue mirage wasn’t fading. At least, not fast enough to put the race in jeopardy. Biden watched the screen carefully, almost suspicious of what he was seeing unfold. The other shoe was going to drop. It must be coming. He hadn’t seen an election night like this since, what? 2008? And the national spirit had been so different then. So optimistic, so hopeful. Not at all like he had seen these past few months. Could the American people really be feeling this way? Jill reached over and gave his hand an encouraging squeeze.

Lights, and voices, and people. A phone call, a concession? No, Kamala… Congratulating him on a good campaign, expressing her satisfaction with the results. Time for a speech. Already? It wasn’t even Midnight yet…Polls weren’t even closed in Hawaii. Yet it didn’t matter. Biden’s team had encouraged him to stay in DC, to prepare for an early victory speech. Biden thought it was presumptuous, yet here he was. Staffers, guests, supporters cheering him on. He smiled, he waved. This was it, his last campaign, and his biggest victory to date. The podium steadying him, the teleprompters on, he spoke:

“My-my fellow Americans…”

Nothing Ever Happens.

Biden sat patiently as he watched the results trickle in. Kentucky, Trump. Massachusetts, Biden. West Virginia, Trump. Maryland, Biden. The pieces were falling into place. Campaign Staff would filter in and provide words of encouragement. “We feel good about where we are” they would say. “We believe we’re on track to win.” Eventually some of the more predictable swing states would get called too. Ohio would go red, disappointing but not surprising. Virginia stays loyal to the Democrats, a reassuring sign. Colorado and New Mexico, Texas, Iowa, Minnesota - each one would fall into place exactly as they were expected to.

Eventually, it would come down to the same states it always did. Pennsylvania, North Carolina, Wisconsin, Nevada… A sickening familiarity started to set in as each one was called. Biden had seen this map before…hadn’t he? He was feeling a bit confused. What were the chances that things were playing out exactly as they did last time? Someone handed him a phone, he couldn’t tell who. It was Kamala, the race was won. “We did it Joe.” But they already had, hadn’t they? What the hell was this? Time to give a speech, time to go tell the people they had beaten…covid… no, no no - they’d won the election. They’d defeated… Trump… They’d… taken back the White House.

The More Things Change…

Slow. That’s the only way to describe it. The night was slow. Biden had been through this rigmarole enough times to know the drill. Polls close, urban votes pour in, blue mirage, rural votes counteract, red mirage, then the last of the urban votes would trickle in, and a call would be made. That’s how this worked, and that’s what was playing out tonight. Biden sat calmly beside Jill, watching the numbers tick up, watching the states get called. Staffers and advisors would pass by occasionally, providing updates on the data they were seeing internally. “We’re hitting every mark we need to be hitting, everythings on track” they would say. And Biden would wait.

Maybe it was because it was his last race, and maybe he had hoped that he could go out on a high note, but Biden found himself becoming restless the longer it took for them to finally call it. He had earned this win. He had put in the work, his policies were sound, his platform was fair. He had done his best to govern for all Americans. The situation unfolding on the screen told a rerun of 2020, with very little movement in either direction. What a sham. Under normal circumstances, in the time before Trump? This was a blowout. Yet here he was, inching his way towards being in the exact same spot he was four years ago.

The team had kept him at the White House. Easier to prepare for the speech, they said. There wasn’t any rush. The red mirage was shrinking, but they still had time to go before the race would be called officially. Biden was tired. He should be in bed. But sleep wouldn’t really fix it. He was always tired. Eventually it was time. Staffers clapped, Jill hugged him. He got calls from the rest of the family, from Kamala. Time to make a speech. Time to address the people. Time to declare victory once and for all.

Let’s do this... one last time.

Lithonia

It's a few months since that fateful election. American democracy was on the brink of being destroyed. But you - you had managed to save it... in the face of Trumpism. Sure, it was closer than you had hoped, but Trump's time in the wilderness had only made him vicious - stronger - and more vengeful. You begin to make your usual calls, this time it's about... the budget? The Senate Majority leader... whatever his name is, he barely even seems to be paying attention. Nobody gives a fuck.

Pride and Prejudice

Elections are messy, long affairs. Biden knew that better than anyone. You make decisions and you evaluate those decisions and you adjust and you push ahead. You just have to hope that when the chips are down, things fall your way, and trust you did everything you could to make it so. Biden knew this, as he watched the results trickle in throughout the night, the campaign staff pouring over every fluctuation, each new batch of votes. Jill sat by, quiet and patient, while the whole country held its breath. Eventually one state or another would be called, and blow the whole thing open, and that would be it.

Staffers slowly got quieter. Eventually, guests started leaving. Kamala, god bless her, called to check in. It was becoming more apparent by the minute. It wasn’t going to happen, the votes were just too far out of reach. Eventually, the call came in and it was official. Just like that, a lifetime of service was coming to an end. People would say that Biden should have known when to quit, that he was greedy for running again. This outcome could have been avoided, if Biden just had the guts to do what was needed for the good of the party and the good of the country.

With the race as close as it was, there was no doubt people would question if someone younger, someone more capable could have dragged this thing across the finish line. Regardless of what his time in office had amounted to, regardless of what remained after he’d gone, this burden would weigh on his legacy for decades. Someone put a phone in his hand. It was time, time to concede the race. He’d never formally conceded like this - he’d dropped out of primaries, but to actually concede, one last political first to round off his time as a civil servant. The phone rang, and he waited for it all to be over.

Where pride failed, vanity would remain.

What once were considered swing states were being called at poll closing time. What should have been safe states for Biden were taking too long to call. Biden kept a brave face. What else could he do? He’d made his bed, and now he was lying in it. Before long, the race was over.

Wilmington Station

It was faster than it should have been. Biden knew that things were not looking promising going into tonight. No matter how sounds his record was, his opponents managed to spin it against him. He thought back to ‘92, when he’d watched Clinton do the same thing to the Republicans. Still, he’d thought he would at least be able to hold the base together, put on a respectable showing, retire with dignity and prop up the party for ‘28. What was unfolding on screen was not that. This was a referendum on the party that would call for redrawing the platform from the ground up. Clearly what they were doing wasn’t working.

It didn’t take long for the staffers to stop coming in with updates. Why bother? The news coverage was plain enough - this was over for the Democrats. Time to lick their wounds and start planning ahead. But not for Biden. These results were a messy, final sign off for his public life and legacy. Whatever the narrative became on his Presidency in years to come, he doubted he would be around long enough to outlast the bitterness of this night.

Eventually, Rodriguez came in. “Its time” she was saying. “They won’t wait any longer. They’re going to go out and speak to their people whether we call them or not…” Biden thought about Wilmington. The staff had convinced him to stay in DC for the evening, but given the circumstances, he would have much rather been there, at home, where the weight of the country felt a little less…persistent. Now that the people had spoken, now that they’d made it clear they didn’t want him, the least he was owed was the comfort of his own home. Finally, he spoke. “Make the call”.

The Apprentice

Joe Biden was not a selfish person.

At least, he didn’t feel he was. He had after all stood aside when the party had insisted he was simply too old to run again.

He thought of himself as, on the whole, pretty reasonable. He put his country first, over party and legacy; he prioritized the good of the people. It was with that in mind that he had handed the torch over to his protégé and watched as she ran on all of his merits while washing her hands of any of her faults.

Based on what was unfolding on screen, it had worked. All returns were positive, Republican surges from rural areas were trickling in at lower rates than had been anticipated - Harris was leading in every major swing state, and it looked like this would all be wrapped up before midnight.

Biden knew he should be happy. Ecstatic really. This was a true mandate - Democrats would control both chambers of congress, Harris would have her say over any supreme court vacancies. She could continue their mandate, and this time she wouldn’t be groveling for every vote. Even Barack back in ‘08 had had to compete with some of the blue dog Democrats that were clinging on to a bygone era. Most of them had been weeded out in midterms or retired, so now Harris was looking at a mostly aligned Democratic Congress. She could accomplish more than any Democrat had in decades.

Yet, Biden still felt a pang of dissatisfaction. He knew that when he had bowed out, it had put the party at a more strategic advantage. He could see the polls improving over time once Harris had taken the reigns, but to see a result like this - such a commanding victory - he had to wonder.. How much of this was Harris and how much of it was the actions of his administration?

Surely, he couldn’t be so disliked that he was the deciding factor between a landslide victory and a loss? Surely for the American people to be this enthusiastic about giving Democrats another term in power, they thought Biden had done something right? After all, how else could a candidate who had polled less than 1% in the 2020 primaries make such a political turnaround, if not by riding his coattails?

Across town at Howard University, Kamala was preparing her victory speech. She thought to Joe, sitting alone at the White House. She knew that he had played a pivotal role in bringing her to this point, and she was grateful. But she also knew that he had stepped out for a reason, and she made a vow to herself that these next four years would not just be about continuing Joe Biden’s legacy, but creating one of her own.

Biden could feel himself being left in the past already. It was as if he was already fading into the footnotes of political science textbooks. An aide came in to ask him if he wanted to call the President-Elect. He shook his head. “Just tell her team to let her know I say ‘congrats kid’. I’ll call her tomorrow.”

Tomorrow he could put on the smile and be the dutiful mentor. Tomorrow he could pass the torch to the next generation as they surpassed anything he ever dreamed of.

He wanted to hold on to today for just a little while longer.

`) //e.image = "" e.executable.push([0, (() => {e.image = e.image = 'https://itsastronomical.com/assets/2024/endings/side.png'})]) } else if (quickstats[0] >= 350 && running == false) { e.pages.push(`

Take Her to the Moon For Me…

The night had been bittersweet.

Biden sat in the private residence of the White House, alone, watching the late night election coverage.

The race had been called some time ago. It looked to be a commanding victory for Harris. He was proud… He had told her so when he spoke to her earlier in the evening. The returns in the House were good, the returns in the Senate seemed to be on track for them to hold.

As he watched the pundits talking about demographic shifts and late vote counts, he knew he’d made the right choice. Much as it pained him to step down from a job he loved and felt a duty too, Kamala had breathed a life into the party that he just couldn’t muster anymore. It reminded him of when he had first ran alongside Barack…

He thought about all the things he had hoped to do but couldn’t, for one reason or another. He sighed. Presidents rarely get to pass much of their agenda - especially with such a slim majority in congress. But now Harris had gained a real mandate - the country chose her, resoundingly. Now she had the opportunity to forge her administration as she saw fit, and take on the cornerstone issues of American politics.

He found himself sorely longing for such a mandate. Had he been given the opportunity, if all his former friends in congress hadn’t dug in their heels and refused to work with him…

Biden couldn’t help but feel like it was his destiny to be a stepping stone. Twice now he had supported Democratic leaders to commanding victories, but in his own efforts he had fallen short, had been given only enough to get by, but not nearly enough to get anything done.

He had hopes for Kamala. He wanted to believe that she could codify Roe, help soften the conservative streak on the Supreme Court, expand his infrastructure bill and maybe even more… He hoped that she could surpass his own accomplishments, and Obama’s and Clinton’s as well - he wanted desperately to see her thrive as a leader.

He wanted her to go the distance. Go save America… and take her to new heights…

Viva La Vida

He used to rule the world.

He used to helm the greatest military on Earth, led by way of freedom and democracy.

Now he was watching as his party outgrew him. He had bowed out because he knew that he had done all that he could for the country. To try and cling to power now would mean to burn down the legacy he had built.

It was better this way. He had seamlessly passed the torch to a new generation of leaders. He had left his mark on the great American story. He had defended Democracy, led the nation out of a pandemic, passed some of the most progressive legislation ever. He had done everything he had set out to.

Why did it feel so sad?

He should be smiling. He should be calling her to congratulate her on her victory. He should be out there ushering in the new age of Democratic leadership like everyone else. Yet, in his wrinkled hands, his weak hands… he felt a desperate melancholy. The sun was setting on his time. He got a glimpse of himself in the mirror. When had he gotten so old? Had he looked like this his whole presidency? No wonder the people were skeptical of him now…

It seemed like only yesterday he had lost Neilia… and Amy… Beau, he had only died… what, eight years ago now? That couldn’t be right, could it…?

He still remembered his first time on the Senate floor. He remembered announcing his first bid for the presidency at Wilmington Station back in ‘88. Being sworn in as Vice President… He used to be a tour de force in the Democratic Party - always part of the conversation, always forging the path forward. He had brought ideas into the mainstream that his colleagues had avoided for years.

He had been in the game for over 50 years. He couldn’t imagine waking up and doing anything different…

But that was when he ruled the world.

`) //e.image = "" e.executable.push([0, (() => {e.image = e.image = 'https://itsastronomical.com/assets/2024/endings/viva.png'})]) } else if (quickstats[0] >= 270 && running == false) { e.pages.push(`

Running Up That Hill

It was a bittersweet moment.

Standing in the Howard University green room, watching the new President-Elect speak to thousands of her ecstatic supporters, Biden couldn't help but feel… conflicted.

Despite what many rank and file Democrats thought, being a one-term President wasn't easy. When he had begun to think about not seeking re-election, anyone and everyone had told him he was making a mistake. They said Harris wasn't up to it. They said the primary would be messy. They said it would be another '68. Even Jill had said that he 'shouldn't give up'.

But at the end of the day, the hardest person to convince was himself. On too many occasions, he'd spent sleepless nights pouring over polls, reading and rereading what the Beltway had to say, worrying about the worst happening. It was only his faith, both in God and the people, that had kept him upright and sane.

Still, even now, a big part of him wished it was him on that stage, giving his speech to his supporters. He had worked so, so hard, and done so, so much. But once again, his dreams had been deferred. After everything, this self denial just felt like a final added insult to injury.

It wasn't like everything had gotten easier either. The road to Inauguration Day would be a messy one, and a likely Republican Senate was certainly not going to help.

Snapping out his thoughts, the President glanced back up at the mass of TVs. All the stations, even Fox, had called it for Harris. It really was happening. He really had made the right decision. In an instant, all of Biden's doubt, all his regret, melted away.

Because of his decision, the MAGA Republicans were routed for the third time. Because of his decision, millions of people would not go hungry or become homeless. Because of his decision, millions of young girls would have a President that they could look up to. He hadn't taken the easy path; he had taken the right one.

"Mr President? I think the President-Elect wants you to go on now."

Realising that he had almost missed his entrance, Biden turned, thanked his aide, and began to make his way onto the stage.

Yes, it was not what he truly wanted. Yes, there had been so much hardship, so much pain, so much… bitterness.

But in this place, in this moment, all he could feel was the sweetness of victory.

An Old Man’s Folly

The President had reclined himself on the couch, slumped, exhausted from the task of governing he felt so paradoxically addicted to. At least his wife Jill was with him though, the only comforting presence in the grand residence where he feels more and more alien as the nights go by. But finally, the campaign season was over.

It seemed akin to a lifetime ago, when the President believed he could be just like the legendary Democratic Presidents of years past. Obama, Clinton, FDR… They all were given the chance to serve two terms, a privilege Joe knew deep down he could never acquire it himself. His political shelf-life was close to expiring, the people’s faith in him was declining. Though he could have run, victory was simply not to be. Maybe in another world…

In his heart, he felt an abated hope, but it was a hope he regardless saw within his VP as she riled up the disciples of the Democratic Party. Yet the optimist and pessimist in his soul were in a bitter struggle, and this night was not going to settle it until all of the states were called in – that he knew. The cheers at his Vice President’s rallies were roaring, even as her opponent’s momentum never let up in the twilight days of the election season. He wanted to believe – with all of his aging strength – that the American people perceived in her what he sees himself. That their border policy was successful, that she could be unburdened by what was, and what could be. That part he was admittedly envious of, smiling in content to himself as he felt the drying pores and wrinkles on his hands. Then his eyes turned to the glassy screen.

The night progressed at a slug’s pace, the race crawling and dragging its stress-brimming mass, as the voices endlessly intoned numbers and opinions on the events unfolding. All of the expected states fell into their expected columns: the Montanas, the Californias, and the other smaller states not worth any of the advertising distributors’ time. But the marginals – by God the marginals – they refused to let themselves cast one candidate to the losing abyss. The looming bars of red and blue did not waver in staying seemingly nanometres away from the mythical 270 mark.

Joe could only imagine how Kamala must be feeling right now.

“What is going on?” Joe muttered to himself. Jill looked on in patient silence, sharing and exchanging alike emotions and expressions to her octogenarian husband. The calamity – the damn absurdity – of the night was not over. As the sun began to show its golden hue under the horizon, the result of the night was finally announced…

… A deadlock, neither candidate reached the winning total of electoral votes.

Joe quietly laughed to himself in the expanding room, the air sinking onto his body. Of course. Of course, after everything he had been through. The death of his first wife and daughter. His disaster in ‘88. The death of his dear son Beau. It all culminated in this. Neither a win, nor a loss. Just an eternal wait in the purgatory of politics.

The House delegation – he knew in his heart of hearts – was not going to go with Kamala. Never.

The job he started was never finished by the woman who was ordained to carry the torch, perhaps the hand holding it was the wrong one after all.

The Blood Red Tide

It was over.

Standing in the Howard University green room, Biden felt every fiber of his being unite in sorrow. Up until this moment, he had hoped. Yes, the polls weren't amazing, but they didn't look great in 2012, either. Yes, early counting favoured `+ opLast + `, but when didn't it? Yes, the GOP were overperforming in must win counties, but the Electoral College was about states, not towns and cities.

Now, however, the delusion that had ensnared him ceased. Kamala Harris had lost, and `+ opName + ` had won. The TVs confirmed this, with their fancy little maps showing the nightmare unfolding; state after state dyed a deep shade of red.

He had made a terrible choice with her. Harris had served her purpose in 2020, but she was not Presidential material. Her stilted campaigning, her uninteresting and poorly communicated policies, all of it just didn't work. It couldn't have worked. Was he perfect? Of course not! But only God knew how much he had done to help his party. Work that she had just thrown away.

He turned to look at the Vice President. She did not turn to look at him.

He went back further. He thought of the primaries, where he had buried his doubts and enthusiastically endorsed Ms Harris. What a fool he had been. He thought of the border... crisis. She had been sent down south to help coordinate relief. It had amounted to nothing. He thought of the debates in 2019. She had insulted him, tried to use his past against him. Did she have any idea how he had helped build the modern face of the party she called home? He-

"Darling?"

The President snapped back. It was Jill. Beautiful Jill.

"I think we should go."

Biden sighed. With his head hung low, he took his wife's hand and began to leave.

"It's alright, Joe. You did your best. Everyone did."

With the depressing chatter behind him grew hazy and faint, the President cast his mind to the future. Truth be told, he did not know what was going to happen now. With congress, with the Beltway, with anything.

But for the first time in many, many years, he simply did not care.

The Darkest Hour

It was a cold and dreary morning. The weak November sun was yet to arrive, and the Bidens' Reheboth residence was still cloaked in darkness, as if nothing beyond it existed.

Yet the President, hunched over his dining table, could still feel the agonising weight of the world on his shoulders.

Where had it all gone wrong? When he had decided to deny himself a second term, it had felt like a sacrifice. He would suffer, yes, but in turn the nation would prosper. Now, though, it seemed that the only thing he sacrificed was his very own party. The folks back in D.C. had tried to comfort him, tell him that it was the Vice President's loss, not his. He saw through their lies. At the end of it all, this election had been a referendum on his record; his presidency. And in one night, the American people had completely and utterly rejected it. Rejected him.

Standing up, the President meekly shuffled over to check the answering machine. There was one new message.

"Hey Joe. It's uh, Barack. I just wanted to say that me and Michelle are with you during these, uh, difficult times. You know, in John 16-"

Click. Biden put his hands on the counter, continuing to stare at the now muted device with a blank expression. How had it come to this? Here he was, the most powerful man in the world, shuttered up in his home, unable to even look at his wife or hear his close friend's voice. Was his faith being tested? Is this how Job felt?

He couldn't take it anymore. Without thinking, Biden moved to the front door. Leaving his house, he moved onto the asphalt, past the agent outside, and down the road. Before long, his shoes were planted on the beach, his eyes fixated on the distant horizon.

The sun had just barely surfaced, and even then, it was so cloudy that only faint light could be perceived. Yet still, the President continued to stare. The Republican trifecta, Project 2025, the millions of vulnerable people, all of it was back on the dining table, back in D.C. Right here, right now, there was just Joseph Biden Jr. and the unseen sun.

And in that moment, something deep within the President stirred. He knew the sun would not appear today. Or tomorrow. It would not appear for a very, very long time. But one day, he would come down to the beach, plant his shoes on the sand, and at last, bask in the rays of the unobscured sun.

It was a cold and dreary morning. But nonetheless, the morning had arrived.

Freedom

This was vindication. To every joke cracked about her 2020 primary performance, her race, her gender, her supposed inexperience. For all the bullshit narratives about her being the “Border Czar” or how her laugh was unhinged. For every person who mispronounced her name on purpose, who said that she was nothing more than a DEI hire, that she didn’t have what it takes - America had vindicated Kamala Harris tonight.

The road that led her here tonight was fraught. First in 2020, people assumed it was skin color that had landed her the vice presidential slot - in actuality, she had always attributed it to her willingness to go for the jugular against Biden, despite him being above her weight class. In 2024, her fight was entirely different - now she was on board, but it was a sinking ship and all hands were on deck. She knew that Biden’s decision to drop out at the 11th hour was a difficult one… But based on tonight, it was also the correct one. Despite all the odds against her, Kamala had won one of the largest victories for the Democratic Party in decades.

The polls were still closing on the West coast as she was preparing her victory remarks. She could already sense the excitement of the crowd waiting outside at Howard University, her Alma Mater, a powerful place to mark her claim on the history books. The only moment she took pause was when she was handed a phone, and instead of the concession she had expected, she found that Joe was calling to be “the first to congratulate you, kid.” Despite everything, she was touched by the emphasis he had put on supporting her, and she promised him to do her best to protect his legacy, their legacy, in the coming years. And the next thing she knew, it was time to make her speech.

She stared out at the crowd and nation, the chanting, the cheering, her mandate unfolding before her. She thought of everything that brought her to this moment, every obstacle she had to overcome.

Because a winner doesn’t quit on themselves.

Yes She Can

So she was prepared for a long, tense, and slow night of watching every new batch of votes that came in.

The American people had seen the two messages put out by the parties, and they chose Freedom. They chose unity. They chose…hope. And it felt fantastic.

The energy in the room was only escalating. It wouldn’t be long now, just another call or two - the West Coast would probably put them over the top, and this would be over. She hoped she could do him justice.

She should have been used to this. 2020 was a brutal crawl to victory that took days to decide. She remembered the day they’d won like it was yesterday. Somehow, tonight was worse - probably because she knew that they would have an answer soon, yet not soon enough. Or maybe because tonight, it was her name on the line. But finally, the swing states started making their calls, and she could see that they had pulled this thing off.

The other side was… Angry, mistrusting. She expected that. She knew that the wounds on the nation ran deep. But if there was one thing she had learned from four years serving under President Joe Biden, it's that decency counts for something.

She stepped out to meet the crowd, anxiously awaiting her victory speech. As she looked out at them, she could see the nation, and the legacy that Biden had laid before her. She made one solemn promise that night.

She would finish the job that she and Biden had started.

"The Truths We Hold"

A Comedy of Errors

As Harris watched the results trickling in, she found her mind drifting back to 2016. Firstly, because it was the election that had elevated her to the national level. She might have been running for a statewide office, but it was to serve in the United States Senate, and she never would have been here without that stepping stone.

Secondly, she remembered the feelings that came as she and the nation realized the election was lost, and the ensuing discussions, debates, dissections and autopsies of the failed Clinton campaign. The election had been so close, by such a small margin that nobody could decide on one particular issue that had ultimately made the difference. Some blamed Clinton - her campaign style, her decisions on the trail. Those who were more sympathetic, like Harris, blamed things like the Comey letter, or the inherent sexism that comes from 8 years living under an African American President and struggling to digest even more radical change.

2024 was not 2016. The path leading to tonight hadn’t looked anything like other Democratic campaigns for decades. And yet, with a sinking feeling, Harris noticed many markers of 2016 in the way the results were pouring in. Some of the numbers just weren’t quite adding up, and it was looking more and more like she would fall just short of the coveted 270 mark.

Harris swallowed. The world had not been kind to Clinton in the wake of 2016. They had branded her as arrogant, unlikeable, shrewd and opportunistic. If things were shaking out that way again, what would Harris’ legacy be? A usurper who put her own ambitions over the legacy she and Biden had built together? A radical who had no business running a national campaign? Her stomach turned with the thoughts that her name and the word “DEI” would be intrinsically linked for the rest of her life..

The truth was, she had done her best - with about 3 months to cobble together a campaign, she had tried to salvage the Democratic Party from the trajectory it had been on. Seemingly, the numbers had shown an improvement from where they were under Biden, but she knew the question would always hang over her campaign - was Biden dropping out really the right call? Was Harris really the right successor? It seemed that yet again, any slight change could have changed the outcome of the night…

Harris let out a long sigh. It was what it was now, it was too late to change anything. People would speculate all they wanted - but finally, after 3 months of non-stop campaigning, she could finally afford a moment of respite.

It was time to bring out the Doritos.

What Was

The build up to tonight had been unlike anyone had ever seen.

Presidential Campaigns tended to be marathons, not sprints, starting usually close to a year prior to election day. For Harris to try to pull together a national campaign in only 3 months, even while using Biden’s campaign infrastructure as a blueprint, was nothing short of a miracle.

Harris reminded herself of this as every call was made, every vote tallied. For every electoral vote she gained, she considered it one more vote she delivered to a party under fire. After all, when a candidate is chosen through the primaries and makes the decision to drop out only weeks ahead of the convention, what can anyone expect but chaos and calamity.

That was not what Harris had experienced over the past 3 months. With every rally, every speech, she saw efficiency, enthusiasm, and a renewed sense of hope. What had felt like a death march to election night had turned into something better - something she could be proud of. So even as the night wore on, and it became more apparent that she would lose the election, Harris found herself filled with an odd sense of pride

It seemed that, despite their best efforts, they’d failed to close that gap and secure the election. In fact, if the numbers were to be believed, she would be losing by a wider margin than any Democrat since the 1980’s. And yet… She had still outperformed expectations, and had brought the party to a softer landing than anyone had expected 6 months ago.

Looking at the numbers pouring in, Harris didn’t feel like she was witnessing a referendum on her, but on her party, who had admittedly fumbled this year, had tried to course correct too little too late - but even if the party would need to spend time licking its wounds, even if they were on track to lose both chambers along with the White House, Harris knew that she could at least walk away with her head held high.

She knew that there were Americans who were disappointed - Americans who would be hurting from tonight's result. She would reach out to them, do what she could to reassure them, to give them a beacon in the darkness. But in this moment, while her team prepared her concession, the pundits made those final few calls, feeling Dougie squeezing her hand, Kamala was filled with one overwhelming sentiment:

Acceptance for what was, in the context of all that had been.

If you're seeing this, you've done something odd. Or I've coded something wrong. Get into contact with Astro and provide as much info as possible.

Shapiro Trails Kemp, Both Nationally And In Key Swing States

August 13th, 2028 | The New York Times

Brian Kemp may have only narrowly clinched the Republican Party mantle from Ohio Senator JD Vance, but don’t be fooled - even the disunited Republican Party holds a sizable lead against the Democratic Party. The latest New York Times/Siena poll following both conventions places former Georgia Governor Brian Kemp in a commanding position with 48% of the electorate saying they will vote for him, compared to only 42% of voters expressing support for Governor Josh Shapiro of Pennsylvania.

It's not even good news in Shapiro's home state of Pennsylvanaia - statewide polling also showed Kemp leading in the state with 46% of the vote compared to Shapiro's 41%. Our poll also found that Senator Fetterman's 'Forward' campaign is struggling badly and may only be serving the Democratic campaign in the state - former Representative Conor Lamb leads with 40% of the vote, compared to outgoing Treasurer Stacy Garrity's 33% and Fetterman's 17%.

Kemp's nomination seems to be a break away from the so-called 'Trump Era', something that many voters appear grateful for. 65% of voters said they were glad the Republicans nominated a 'non-MAGA' candidate, while 32% said they were not glad by the decision.

The poll also found that the biggest factor for Shapiro's struggles was the sheer unpopularity of President Joe Biden and Acting President Kamala Harris, who has taken the duties of the office since Biden's stroke earlier in February. The current administration has a 36% approval rating and a 59% disapproval rating - one of the widest gaps to ever be recorded in modern history. 52% of voters also say that Biden should be more permanently removed from office and that Harris should become President until next inaguration.

Voters Reluctant as Trump Mulls Fourth Presidential Campaign.

November 23rd, 2026 | The New York Times

Hot off a less-than-terrible midterm for the Democratic Party - holding the House of Representatives by a single seat and flipping control of the United States Senate, Republicans are left with little to celebrate. The party made net gains in the gubernatorial races, winning open seats in Kansas and Michigan while unseating Governor Katie Hobbs in Arizona, and are left searching for answers, and a leader, ahead of the 2028 Presidential Elections.

However, despite former President Trump being interested in another campaign, voters both nationally and within the Republican party seem reluctant to give him a second shot after his defeat in 2024 - especially given his current prison sentence.

The latest New York Times/Siena polling as the President down by 3%, with President Harris claiming 47% of voters nationally while 44% say they would vote for Donald Trump. 7% say they are undecided, and 2% express interest in voting for another candidate.

Republican primary voters were also polled in another poll ran in parallel with the hypothetical general election polling. Only 42% of Republicans said they would vote for Trump in the primaries, followed by outgoing Florida Governor Ron DeSantis at 20%, former Virginia Governor Glenn Youngkin at 15%, and the remaining 22% of voters declaring their support for other candidates or are undecided as of now.

This is in stark contrast to what polling looked like four years ago, ahead of the 2024 elections - Mr. Trump held leads in both the Republican primary and general election polling.

Currently, no candidate has formally declared their intention to run for the nomination, and Mr. Trump's 42% of the vote seems difficult for any single candidate to overcome. However, the field seems largely frozen as Trump's allies are looking towards a hearing in March of next year that could potentially see Mr. Trump released early - something that would, according to these allies, move him to run again.

AP: Cava beats Gaetz, Ends 27 years of Republican Gubernatorial Dominance in Florida.

TALLAHASSEE, Fla. (AP) - Miami-Dade County Mayor Daniella Levine Cava won the race to succeed Florida Governor Ron DeSantis on Tuesday in a sweeping victory over Republican Matt Gaetz, becoming both the first woman to become Governor of Florida, and the first Democrat in nearly three decades.

Cava’s victory marks a reversal of Florida’s rightward shift, with many Democrats hoping her focus on issues impacting Florida’s funding of affordable housing programs and environmentalism can be a blueprint towards being competitive once again in the sunshine state.

“Instead of boxing with shadows for two terms, I hope to make life better for everyone here in Florida. We will amend the broken insurance system that leaves our families vulnerable. We will do our part in stopping the climate trends that have led to our state being the home turf for hurricanes,” Cava told her supporters during her victory speech, “and we will truly create an equitable Florida for all.”

In the lead-up to the election, DeSantis’ administration faced crisis after crisis. With the collapse of the insurance market in Florida and the state lacking the funds to properly assist homeowners through the state’s insurance program, Florida briefly entered bankruptcy. The teacher’s strike of 2025 put another setback in DeSantis’ second term, with teachers demanding more academic freedom in the face of DeSantis’ “anti-woke crusade” and attempts to fire large numbers of teachers. Political commentators have long suggested that the struggles of DeSantis’ administration led to Former Representative Matt Gaetz triumphing over Representative Byron Donalds and Miami Mayor Francis Suarez.

Despite winning by a relatively wide margin, Governor-Elect Cava will have to work with solid Republican majorities in both chambers of the Florida legislature. Split-ticket voting was unusually high in this election, likely due to the Department of Justice bringing charges against Gaetz during the campaign.

“I’m generally a fan of conservative ideas,” one voter explained to AP News following the election, “but Gaetz is just a bridge too far. I’d hate to see him run this state even further into the ground than DeSantis.”



----
Learn more about the issues and factors at play in the midterms at https://apnews.com/hub/explaining-the-elections

----
And follow the AP’s election coverage of the 2026 elections at https://apnews.com/hub/2026-midterm-elections.

----
Associated Press reporter Sam Meyer contributed from Orlando, Florida.

Microsoft Announces AI-focused Phone, Releases Spring 2028

Wired | August 18th, 2027 | This will be the first major launch since former Presidential candidate Doug Burgum became CEO of the company

Microsoft CEO Doug Burgum today surprised nearly everyone and announced that the company would make another entry into the cellular phone market, with the announcement of the CoPilot Genesis, a new, AI-centric cell phone meant to learn and accomodate the user over time.

Burgum told the crowd at 'Microsoft Press Event 2027' that Microsoft spent much of their efforts over the last few years to build an advanced, artificial intelligence system capable of not just learning, but applying data gathered across the use of the phone to help draft emails, automate tasks, use battery power efficiently, set sleep schedules, generate and sort images, among other things.

Boasting a custom Microsoft Azure AI Neural Processor, a Snapdragon 9 Gen 2 chip, one terabyte of storage, and a bezelless high-resolution OLED display, the claimed specs of the CoPilot Genesis are impressive. But so were the specs of the last phone Microsoft attempted, and it never caught onto the global market.

So, what's different this time, other than the presence of artificial intelligence? Burgum has claimed that this will not be a new "Windows phone" but will feature a new operating system built from the ground up to be intuitive, capable, and designed around artificial intelligence. Although some have derided Microsoft's re-entry into the smartphone market (a clip of former Microsoft CEO Steve Ballmer predicting the failure of the iPhone in 2007 made the rounds online recently), the picture painted by Burgum is giving industry insiders serious pause.

The CoPilot Genesis' AI is apparently '500 times as capable as competitors' - likely referring to Apple Intelligence, which is a part of the Siri ecosystem. Burgum goes on further to talk about how advanced the predictive system is - after only a few months of learning, the phone can practically 'read your mind' - or so he says. The best part? Burgum announced the price at the event - the CoPilot Genesis will launch at only $700, hundreds of dollars cheaper than the current iPhone 18 on store shelves.

This bombshell of an announcement puts the pressure on Apple - due to release a new phone next month, to respond. Apple, which has been struggling somewhat in the phone market, is set to release either the iPhone 19 or the iPhone 20/XX next month (There have been conflicting reports about what this new phone will be called). In any case, Apple, the dominant phone manufacturer should be prepared for battle with Microsoft.

News Release – Bureau of Labor Statistics

For release 10:00 a.m. (ET) Tuesday, January 28, 2028 | USDL-28-0105

Technical Information: (202) 691-6378 • cpsinfo@bls.gov • www.bls.gov/cps • Media Contact: (202) 691-5902 • PressOffice@bls.gov

Union Members – 2027

The union membership rate – the percent of wage and salary workers who were members of unions – was 14.2% in 2027, showing a continuation in the sharp rise in the union membership rate since 2024, the U.S. Bureau of Labor Statistics reported today. The number of wage and salary workers belonging to unions, at 20.5 million, also showed strong signs of growth. In 1983, the first year for which comparable data are available, the union membership rate was 20.1 percent and there were 17.7 million union members.

These data on union membership are collected as part of the Current Population Survey (CPS), a monthly sample survey of about 60,000 eligible households that obtains information on employment and unemployment among the nation’s civilian noninstitutional population age 16 and over. For further information, see the Technical Note in this news release.

Highlights from the 2027 data:

  • The union membership rate of public-sector workers (40.3 percent) continued to be significantly higher than the rate of private-sector workers (11.5 percent). (See table 3.)
  • The highest unionization rates were among workers in education, training, and library occupations (50.3 percent) and protective service occupations (43.6 percent). (See table 3.)
  • Women have, for the first time since we’ve collected gender-segregated data, achieved a higher rate of unionization (15.3 percent) than men (13.4 percent). (See table 1.)
  • Black workers remained more likely to be union members than White, Asian, and Hispanic workers. (See table 1.)
  • Nonunion workers had median weekly earnings that were 85 percent of earnings for workers who were union members ($1,138 versus $1,337). (The comparisons of earnings in this news release are on a broad level and do not control for many factors that can be important in explaining earnings differences.) (See table 2.)
  • Among states, Ohio, Hawaii, and New York had the highest union membership rates (35.4 percent, 30 percent, and 23.3 percent, respectively), while the lowest rates were in North Carolina (3.3 percent), South Dakota (4.6 percent), and South Carolina (5.1 percent). (See table 5 and chart 1.)
`) //e.image = "" e.executable.push([1, (() => {e.image = e.image = 'https://itsastronomical.com/assets/2024/endings/labstat.png'})]) if (used != true) { const playlist = new Playlist(); const song = new Song( "30 For 30", "SZA & Kendrick Lamar", "https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/a/af/SZA_-_Lana_%28SOS_Deluxe%29.png", "https://audio.jukehost.co.uk/Clk8aEYBWSczxnp48hjmMaIKtNheFwQB" ); playlist.addSong(song); changePlaylist(playlist); used = true; } } else if (quickstats[0] >= 270 && campaignTrail_temp.candidate_json[2]["fields"].last_name == "Trump Jr.") { ctsAchievement("Binding of Isaac"); e.pages.push(`

Dust Settles On Midterms As Trumpworld Moves Focus To 2028

CNN.com | November 30th, 2026 | GOP gains in the House swell to 250, as a reinvigorated GOP focuses on how to win the next Presidential campaign

With the final races called - the new Congress settles in at the largest GOP House Majority since 1928, and the largest Republican Senate Majority since 2004.

Among the shock losses include both of the Rio Grande Valley seats to Republican challengers, eight Democratic House seats alone in California, and 22-term Ohio Representative Marcy Kaptur. With all said and done, the party will gain 41 House Seats to bring their total to 251.

The Republican Party also flipped four Senate seats - with outgoing Governor Brian Kemp defeating incumbent Jon Ossoff in Georgia, and picking up three more seats from retiring incumbents in Michigan, Minnesota, and New Hampshire.

Gubernatorial elections were also a success for the GOP - along with flipping open seats in Kansas, Maine, Wisconsin, and Michigan, the party also ousted unpopular incumbents in Oregon, Arizona, and most notably - New York.

These victories, of course, have Trumpworld scrambling. While former President Donald Trump and his son, Donald Trump Jr. were off the trail due to legal issues, the former President and his son seem eager to claim these victories as a mandate for their de-facto leadership of the party.

Donald Trump Jr. has reportedly called up Speaker-designate Lisa McClain of Michigan and Senate Majority Leader John Thune to discuss party operations, and is eager to meet with both at Mar-A-Lago.

Key takeaways from Trump’s ‘Liberation Day’ tariffs

April 2nd, 2025 | CNN.com

Washington (CNN) — President Donald Trump on Wednesday unveiled expansive new tariffs in a major escalation of his trade war, referring to the historic move as a “declaration of economic independence.” Trump’s risky bet to address unfair trade practices could send prices higher for American consumers and weaken economic growth, according to most economists.

Using national emergency powers, Trump announced 10% tariffs on all imports into the United States, and even higher tariffs on goods from about 60 countries or trading blocs that have a high trade deficit with the US. That includes China and the European Union, which will be levied new duties of 34% and 20%, respectively.

Trump’s “Liberation Day” announcement did little to clear the dense fog of uncertainty. And even more tariffs by sector are coming down the pike, senior White House officials said Wednesday on a phone call with reporters. Here are key takeaways from Trump’s sweeping tariff hike.

New tariffs have entered the chat

Trump’s so-called reciprocal tariffs won’t match the ones foreign countries impose on the United States unless a country already had a 10% US tariff. They also won’t stack on top of existing duties by sector.

“We will charge them approximately half of what they are and have been charging us, so the tariffs will be not a full reciprocal,” Trump said from the Rose Garden on Wednesday afternoon. “I could have done that, I guess, but it would have been tough for a lot of countries and we didn’t want to do that.”

American businesses are bracing for the fallout

Tariff hikes inflict higher costs on US-based importers, which are typically passed on to American businesses. Many of them said on Wednesday they’re bracing for the fallout of Trump’s latest actions.

“It’s concerning, it’s going to be expensive, it’s going to require us all to make decisions,” Benjamin Colvin, president and co-founder of Devil’s Foot Brewing in Asheville, North Carolina, said Wednesday at a news conference with other business owners in the state. Colvin said that his company, which produces craft sodas and zero-proof cocktails, has already seen production costs ratchet higher since Trump slapped tariffs on aluminum and steel.

`) //e.image = "" e.executable.push([1, (() => {e.image = e.image = 'https://itsastronomical.com/assets/2024/endings/tariffs.png'})]) if (used != true) { const playlist = new Playlist(); const song = new Song( "Apple", "Charli XCX", "https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/6/60/Charli_XCX_-_Brat_%28album_cover%29.png", "https://audio.jukehost.co.uk/63AnSnkiw7gbvIeegxuI0RxfsikkCz14" ); playlist.addSong(song); changePlaylist(playlist); used = true; } } else if (quickstats[0] < 270 && campaignTrail_temp.candidate_json[2]["fields"].last_name == "Haley") { e.pages.push(`

LIVE: Nikki Haley reshuffles Cabinet

November 10th, 2026 | The New York Times Staff

With Democrats managing to clinch a Senate majority (and a decisive one too, depending on how races in Alaska and Ohio play out), and a lack of confidence in President Haley’s foreign policy missions, rumors have been abound that the President plans on changing certain members of the cabinet in order to give the outgoing Senate time to confirm them.

Sources close to potential victims of this cabinet reshuffle have confirmed said rumors and that Haley will finalize a decision later today. She will have a morning cabinet meeting before embarking on a pre-planned diplomatic trip to Brussels. At the meeting, she is expected to notify the cabinet on the decisions she had made.

The lingering drama to keep in mind is the continuing tension between Haley’s reinvigorated, traditional wing of the GOP, and the populist faction still led by Trump. Both sides of the party have continued to blame one another for the staggering losses in the midterm elections.

Follow along with us live:

______________________________________________________

[10:30 AM] - The Associated Press is reporting that Toomey is out as Secretary of Commerce. We can’t independently confirm this, but if this is true - it would be a stunning dismissal given Toomey’s loyalty to Haley.

[11:03 AM] - We’re independently able to confirm that Toomey is out as Commerce Secretary. Additionally, Christie is out as Attorney General. Christie being out isn't really a surprise - he was always a black sheep in the cabinet, and the struggle to get him confirmed probably cost Haley a lot of political capital she couldn't afford to lose.

[11:22 AM] - Unconfirmed reports that Bob Corker is out as Secretary of State. A mid-term replacement of a Secretary of State is quite an unusual feat, but it would be a massive political victory for Trump and his allies if this is the case.

[11:45 AM] - It appears that the Cabinet meeting has now concluded. Rumors that Burgum is out as Energy Secretary seem to have been false. Haley will speak to the press shortly before departing.

[11:52 AM] - President Haley has appeared at the press briefing room. But in a stunning turnaround, it appears that she's flanked by Donald Trump Jr.

[11:55 AM] - Haley's remarks confirm the rumors of a change in the Cabinet. She argues that the midterms show a loss of confidence in her administration and has made changes needed to prove her willingness to listen to the public.

CNN: Senate Rejects National Six-Week Abortion Ban

WASHINGTON (CNN) – The Senate has rejected a proposed piece of legislation to impose a Six-Week ban on abortion at the national level. This comes as another defeat in a DeSantis administration that has been struggling to make progress on its boldly conservative agenda.

The vote was 49-51, with key swing Senators Murkowski, Collins, and Capito being joined by Senator McCormick, in a surprise defeat to what was seen as an easy victory for the administration.

“I am pro-life,” Sen. McCormick clarified, “but I don’t think the federal government has the right to impose a ban this strict on the states.”

The bill’s defeat, along with the administration’s failed push to raise the retirement age for those receiving Social Security and watered down tax cuts, have left the DeSantis administration scrambling to implement his “Great American Comeback”.

What's Next

Senate Majority Leader John Thune needs to find a way to get his caucus behind the goals of the party, especially as the Republicans face dropping approval ratings.

“We need to have some tact here,” Former Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell told his colleagues in a caucus meeting, “the administration can posture all they’d like, we need to govern.”

DeSantis’ administration faces low approval ratings and has reportedly been exceedingly frustrated by Congressional inaction on these issues. With growing numbers of Americans feeling the country is going in the wrong direction since 2016, we may be entering an American Malaise rather than an American Comeback.

President Burgum is expected to give a Presidential pardon to former President Donald Trump, per reporting both within and outside of the White House. NYT Opinion: Why UAW Refused to Endorse Cooper for Re-Election

August 12, 2032 | By Shawn Fain

I’m going to start this off by saying I’ve been a Democrat my whole life, just as long as I’ve felt empowered by the work my family did in UAW plants. However, there comes a point where you need to face the music about your politics and party, and for us at UAW, it was this year.

I have no idea how we went from President Biden walking picket lines in 2023 to having President Cooper help break strikes in 2031 – just after midterms by the way. Did Democrats seriously think Union Voters, their long time allies, were the reason they were losing?

For a long time, the Democrats have been shifting from a party for the working class to a party for the same rich assholes that control the Republicans, and also happen to own the New York Times. Since my time as President is over I’ll say this – we really swallowed our pride when endorsing President Cooper in 2028. We were worried about a Democrat from a right-to-work state ushering in the next Taft-Hartley, but we wanted to work with our allies either way. We were right to be worried, and wrong to trust the Democrats. I lost my seat at the table by sticking my neck out for Democrats who were unwilling to stick their necks out for us.

Unions have been under attack for decades since Taft-Hartley. The NLRB has been stripped of whatever teeth it had, and trumped up charges of corruption are used the moment union leadership gets uppity while Congresspeople and Supreme Court Justices regularly take free vacations from billionaires.

Unions are done just being a political force for the Democrats with no investment.

If you don’t compete for blue collar voters on economic issues, they’ll vote based on social issues. As someone from a UAW family, who worked in the plants myself, a lot of those people are socially moderate, even conservative. Democrats cannot win union voters without either supporting unions or selling their other constituents down the river. Unless they’re looking to return to being a party of the South, New York State and occasionally the midwest, it is in their best interest to wake the fuck up.

Personally, I wouldn’t settle for anything less than a repeal of Taft-Hartley at this point.

2025 United States Senate special election in Ohio

From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia

The 2025 United States Senate special election in Ohio was held on February 17, 2025, following the election of Senator JD Vance as Vice President of the United States. He assumed the Vice Presidency on January 20, 2025.

The seat had remained vacant from January 20th through the election. Democrat Tim Ryan saw token opposition during the Democratic Primary. In the Republican Primary, Trump backed candidate Frank LaRose beat out Governor Mike DeWine’s supported candidate, Jon Husted.[1][2]

This was Tim Ryan’s second bid for the Ohio Class 3 Senate Seat, having been defeated by JD Vance in 2022.[3] Donald Trump won the state of Ohio in the 2016, 2020, and 2024 presidential elections. Ryan's campaign was considered essential for Democrats' chances to regain the senate majority in 2026.[4]

Although Ryan won 53.31% of the vote, outperforming Sherrod Brown’s failed bid in the 2024 United States Senate election, receiving around 6.8% more of the vote, these results would be contested and ultimately overturned in May of 2025. The Federal Bureau of Investigation, under direction of Kash Patel and the instruction of President Trump, would open an investigation into the integrity of the voting under the Re-PATRIOT Act. [5] The FBI reported over 500,000 unverified votes that were not valid and therefore voided from the total results.

Frank LaRose, who had received 44.49% of the vote on election day, was sworn in as Ohio’s next Class 3 Senator on July 4th, 2025. The victory retained Republican control of both of Ohio's U.S. Senate seats and the U.S. Senate as a whole, setting the backdrop for the Republican supermajorities in both chambers of congress following the 2026 United States Elections.

This was largely considered to be the last free election in the United States.[6]

Who is 'The Rizzler', and why is President Kennedy meeting with him?

March 3rd, 2025 | The Guardian

If there was an article we expected to be writing this year, nothing even close to what we are about to write would be on this list. Nevertheless, here we go.

President Robert F. Kennedy Jr. has recently announced that he will be meeting with a series of social media influencers in order to promote healthy lifestyles. Among these, most famously, are the 'Costsco Guys' and 'The Rizzler', who have become close collaborators over the past few years.

For those wondering, The Rizzler is a seven-year-old boy named Christian who went viral in 2023 for a funny move that is called the 'rizz face', where he strokes his chin and purses lips. Many deem this move to have 'rizz' - which is short for charisma, and it seems the President is looking to take advantage of his 'rizz'.

While not related to the two, The Rizzler began to collaborate with two other influencers - the Costco Guys. The Costco Guys are a father-and-son combo - made up of son Big Justice and father AJ. AJ was an amateur wrestler before he began making a series of TikTok videos with his son, where they review items from Coscto and give them a "BOOM" if they deem them worthy.

But why is President Kennedy meeting with these influencers? The White House has given the usual remarks - that Kennedy has a message he needs to spread to all Americans, even in 'unconventional' ways.

Of course, the President currently has a low approval rating - floating around 37% as of right now, with many unsatisfied about his stances on vaccinations and dietary habits in America. Many respondants have also suggested that the President lacks a cohesive economic agenda, with 67% of voters saying they could not name what exactly he is trying to do in order to improve economic conditions.

If you can, please support us on a monthly basis. It takes less than a minute to set up, and you can rest assured that you’re making a big impact every single month in support of open, independent journalism. Thank you.

NBC | July 19th, 2028

Former officials who worked closely with Biden have come out in recent days following the release of The Book of Revalations by Jake Tapper and Alex Thompson, claiming that the book's contents were largely inaccurate in potraying the situation involving the former President's wellbeing during his second and incomplete term.

The book, encapsulating the escalating political and constitutional crisis that led to Vice President Kamala Harris invoking the 25th Amendment less than two years ago, has recieved praise from critics, but those still loyal to their departed Commander in Chief seem to be eager to discredit the contents of the book.

Opinion: The Biden Wheelchair News Should Not Shock People

The New Yorker | September 14th, 2025

Biden's electoral victory over `+ opLast + ` seemed to have made a lot of people forget the age issue Biden struggled with during much of his first term. It seemed that at the time, for better or for worse, enough of the nation put aside collective concerns about his mental and physical wellbeing to ensure that `+ opLast + ` did not win a term in the White House.

It was wrong, however, to outright reject or gaslight the public about these issues that had sprung up ever since he announced his original campaign in 2019. This collective denial has turned into a spiral of chaos and shock following the recent news that the President will be in a wheelchair going forward. Biden had, through many ways, regained the trust of Americans. He had not righted the ship, but had made progress in the last few years of his term. Americans placed this trust in the fact that they believed Biden would not have run if he did not believe he was up to the task of serving for four more years.

The news that Biden will remain in a wheelchair, at least to the public, is all the more shocking because of this. But it should not shock people. His team lied about his condition, covered it up under the guise of ''defending democracy''. And when we chose to re-elect him with little to no opposition, we became guilty in that coverup too.

The question now is pretty straightforward: What happens next? Do we see actual pushback from Congressional leaders such as Speaker Hakeem Jeffries on this matter? Does Harris and the cabinet invoke the 25th Amendment?

The next questions is more long-term: What have we done? How will America react?

Unfortunately, I believe I know the answer. I believe we have opened a Pandora's box that we cannot shut. America has made a mistake, and those who have enabled him in one form or another - whether by covering up his errors, voting for his renomination, or continuing the lie that Biden was fit to serve - have permanently shattered whatever trust Americans have placed in the political system.

In attempting to stop the rise of right wing extremism, I believe we have only given them the final casus belli they need to destroy our institutions. We are living on borrowed time, and the re-election of Biden last year only allowed us as a country to spend a few extra years digging our grave.

Republicans Back Trillion Dollar Coin, If Trump's Face Can Go On It

CNBC | June 3rd, 2025

The decision by President Joe Biden to mint a trillion dollar coin was one ridiculed by Republicans nationally, and the destruction of the coin was seen as a key pledge by the Republican campaign in 2024.

Dysfunction in Washington, however, may mean that the coin is here to stay longer than expected.

While the House seems unified in passing a 'clean' appropriations bill, there's been a growing movement in the Senate GOP caucus to demand spending cuts before any bill regarding the budget is passed.

This movement, led by Senators Ron Johnson and Marsha Blackburn of Wisconsin and Tennessee respectively, want the GOP to stand firm and block any appropriations bill without monetary concessions.

'We were... elected to prevent this sort of crap.' says Ron Johnson 'I don't see why we should bow to the White House on this matter'.
