538: Why We’re Closing Our Doors

By: Nathaniel Rakich

Over the last few election cycles, we at FiveThirtyEight have centered our reporting around data, particularly polling data, to attempt to better understand the American public. In 2016, when the polls heavily underestimated Donald Trump, many of us were grappling with the question of the legitimacy of our approach for the first time. We thought it may have been the margin or the sampling, and continued to press on.

However, as more elections have taken place and polls have become less and less accurate, we feel as though we’re becoming a modern Literary Digest. We gave Biden a chance below 10% of winning, and he pulled it off. No poll, swing state or national, had him ahead. With `+ opLast + ` winning a 20% chance, we thought it was just a one-in-five chance coming up. However, with the odds for winners continually getting worse, the model we use to forecast probabilities and the data just don’t support our style.

As such, we’ve struck a deal with ABC to integrate our staff into their normal politics reporting team. Our website will remain as an archive to our past work, and our reporters will still be putting in the good work, but FiveThirtyEight is gone until further notice. Should poll accuracy make a recovery in the next few years, we may bring it back, but the trends point in the opposite direction.

Thank you for your years of support, and we hope you’ll stick around with us as a part of ABC’s politics reporting team.

`) //e.image = "" e.executable.push([2, (() => {e.image = e.image = 'https://itsastronomical.com/assets/2024/endings/bidensaid.png'})]) } else if (quickstats[0] >= 270 && speaker == 'Jeffries' && campaignTrail_temp.candidate_json[0]["fields"].last_name == "Biden") { e.pages.push(`

Hakeem Jeffries’ Term as the First Black Speaker of the House.

NPR | March 13th, 2025

Speaker of the House Hakeem Jeffries had a turbulent rise to power, mired in the leadership scramble which surrounded the Biden administration’s first term. Despite it all, he managed a divided Democratic caucus with a thin majority remarkably well, cementing his place among some of the most effective congressional leaders in crisis.

“This has been a fragile moment in our country’s history,” Jeffries told NPR in an interview, “but I’m honored to have the privilege to guide us out of this turbulent moment and into the future. President Biden’s re-election has proven that our leadership has been working for the people.”

While Democrats have increasingly become split between the progressive, liberal, and moderate wings of the party, Jeffries has taken a page out of Former Speaker Nancy Pelosi’s book, of balancing interests and whipping votes as needed to overcome the problem of a slim majority.

When we asked Jeffries about his similar leadership style, he said that “Pelosi was a mentor of mine for a while, with her being the first female Speaker of the House. Her management of the wide array of interests and ideologies within the Democratic caucus were effective, and her ability to broker compromises is legendary.”

Pocketbook Issues, Housing on top of the House Democrats’ Agenda

Jeffries’ mantra when it comes to his legislative focus is that Democrats have "... to make sure that we're focused on housing prices, food prices, gas prices, as well as health care costs, as major drivers of the expenses that everyday Americans confront." While some activists are disappointed at the sidelining of social issues, many Democrats approved of the approach.

Rep. Sarah McBride of Delaware was among the most vocal in her approval, saying that “I was elected to represent the people of Delaware, and they care about their pocketbooks more than what bathroom I use.”

Rep. Jared Golden also approved, saying that “economic issues are the bread and butter of the Democratic party. The further we stray from them, the more we have to lose.”

Time will tell if Jeffries is able to maintain the Speaker’s Gavel going into 2026, but the Democrats are hopeful, as is Jeffries himself.

Democrats to Cut FEC’s Public Election Funding

FOX News | September 18th, 2025

In a move most believe to be a response to Robert F. Kennedy Jr. gaining 5% of the popular vote, some Democrats are moving to end the FEC’s Public Election Funding program, as the insurgent’s “We the People” party would have qualified for matching federal funds.

“I can’t say I’m surprised,” Kennedy told FOX NEWS when asked for a response, “it’s been a long time since the Democratic Party was the party of democracy. My father would be ashamed of the way the party’s went.”

The Kennedy family at large, despite being unified in their opposition to RFK Jr.’s bid, are not unified behind the current Democratic plan of action here, with Joe Kennedy III saying “Look, the guy’s a crank, but the rules are the rules. He won 5% of the vote, and as such is entitled to federal funds. We support campaign finance laws as is.”

Other third party candidates have had mixed reactions to this, with left-wing DEI advocate Cornel West slamming the Democrats, saying that “Kennedy’s insurgent bid is one of the few things that’s been able to challenge the duopoly. He was an unfitting warrior for the cause, but the duopoly is rearing its ugly head to stamp out any opposition as it always does.”

Kennedy has already sued the FEC, and has made it clear that he intends to escalate the case “as far as it needs to go,” making it clear that “I’m a goddamned Kennedy, of course I have the money to take this to the Supreme Court.”

This interesting situation is just another example of the Democrats being hypocrites, slamming President Donald Trump for his abuses of power while never hesitating to abuse that same power themselves.

`) //e.image = "" e.executable.push([2, (() => {e.image = e.image = 'https://itsastronomical.com/assets/2024/endings/speakerjeff.png'})]) } else if (quickstats[0] < 270 && campaignTrail_temp.candidate_json[0]["fields"].last_name == "Biden") { /* Failsave */ e.pages.push(`

Read Barack Obama’s Eulogy for Joe Biden

June 6, 2027 | The New York Times

Former President Barack Obama on Sunday delivered a eulogy on behalf of President Joe Biden at a ceremony at the Holy Trinity Catholic Church, attended by many of Biden’s former colleagues and friends from Capitol Hill. The following is a transcript of those remarks, as prepared by The New York Times.

FORMER PRESIDENT BARACK OBAMA: To Joe’s loving family, to Jill, Hunter, Ashley, the many Biden grandchildren and great grandchildren, Vice President Harris and First Gentleman Emhoff, Mrs. Trump, President and Mrs. Bush, President and Secretary Clinton, Vice President and Mrs. Pence, Vice President Gore, Vice President and Mrs. Quayle, and the friends, family, and colleagues both from within and outside Washington-

It is with great sadness that I am up here speaking today. Joe Biden was a man who devoted himself with utmost pride and fervor to anything he set out for. He was a loving husband, a devoted father, and by far the most diligent public servant I’ve ever had the pleasure of working with.

People forget - Joe and I were not always the perfect team. Before we shared a ticket we had been opponents. He helped shape us into the leaders we are - and he did so with the utmost respect, dignity, and pride. He did the same in the U.S. Senate, where he served for over 3 and a half decades, holding our government to the highest standard of leadership we could muster.

When I decided to ask him to join my ticket in 2008, I knew deep down that I was making the best decision I would make in my entire time as President. Joe Biden was in a league of his own - diligent, resilient, warm. He had invaluable experience that, to date, with no offence to my colleagues in attendance, makes him possibly one of the most overqualified Presidents to ever serve the office.

He and I were different, no doubt. There were many times where I found myself in awe at how easily he could speak to anyone, and how unwaveringly candid he was while doing so. There were times when he would speak up about things that even I found it hard to stand up for.

That really speaks to who Joe was as a leader. Those of us who knew him well knew even in his old age there was an unquenchable fire for justice, for doing the right thing. That fire fueled every decision he made as Senator, Vice President, and eventually as President. He wasn’t concerned about what made him the most electable - he was concerned with what was best for the American people. For anyone who has held this office or any office of leadership, you know - that’s a difficult position to be in. But Joe never wavered from what he thought was right.

In his time as Vice President, he and I have both often mentioned that he would be the last man in the room when making decisions. It’s the same relationship he would later have with his own Vice President. I can honestly say, those were some of the most important, and the most valuable moments of my Presidency. It was those moments that assured me not only that I’d made the right call in asking him to join my administration, but also that I had made a lifelong friend. For all the errors I made during my presidency - and heaven knows there’s plenty of folks out there who say I made a lot of them - I owe many of my successes and victories to his advice and support.

It’s the kind of wisdom that only comes from having been around the block a few times. Joe Biden had been in politics for longer than most of us here, had seen ten different administrations come and go during his political career. And in that time, Joe had overcome hardships that very few of us have had to face, and hopefully never will.

From the very start of his life as a public servant, Joe faced challenges. Before he could even be sworn in for the first time, he had to try and cope with the pain and grief of losing his wife Neilia and daughter Amy, and becoming a single father of two boys. Most people would have hit a wall right then and there, but not Joe. He managed to rise to being both a single dad and a Senator, and he never let himself drop the ball in either arena. That takes the kind of strength of character that only the best of us possess.

That strength didn’t just define who he was as a person but as a leader. He was grounded, in a way that a lot of us in Washington tend to lose touch from. He didn’t let partisan lines define people - he took a person at who they were, not their affiliation, and during his time in congress he managed to make countless friendships on both sides of the aisle, which you can tell just by the people in attendance here today. He believed in common decency, that the people in the other party weren’t your enemy, they just had different priorities. Through that, he did his best to serve not just the people who voted for him, but every American, to ensure no one felt left behind by their government.

Joe wasn’t the perfect man or the perfect leader, but he believed fiercely in the promise of America. He believed in standing by our allies, by our people, and by our values. Even in the rockiest moments of his career, he has had a fierce belief in the good of the American people. It was this belief that led to him running for President in 1988. It was what led him to join my ticket two decades later. It was this belief that helped him make the difficult decision to stand aside in 2016 - a decision to leave the fight to the rest of us while he spent a bit more time with his son Beau before he passed.

And when I say “fight,” let me be clear - I don’t mean fighting against another candidate or party. I mean the fight for the American people. Joe didn’t believe in “us vs. them”. He believed in “us and them”. That’s why he decided to come back and run again in 2020 - so he could start bringing the people together. Because he knew better than most that a united front is the only way through a crisis.

Y’know, Joe didn’t outright say it much, but he took a lot of inspiration from his predecessors when making decisions. Not me, of course - he learnt a lot more from my screw ups, I think. But there were other Presidents, like Kennedy or Lyndon Johnson, that he really aspired to. I think he was most inspired by Franklin Roosevelt, as evidenced by the portrait he kept over the fireplace in the oval. Anyone who takes up the mantle of the presidency knows he or she has big shoes to fill, and all of us want to leave a legacy that lives up to the greats.

Not all of us can live up to that legacy, and not all of us are remembered for what we want to be remembered for - don’t I know - but I think in Joe’s case, he’d be proud of the legacy he’s leaving behind. He may not have done it with the same pomp as some of our fellow presidents, but I know that when I think of his time in office, I will remember how he pulled us out of the depths of a pandemic and left us with rock solid support to our economy, workforce, military, and country. In that way, I can honestly say that Joe lived up to the legacies that he had once aspired to.

So when I remember Joe Biden, I’ll not only think of the loving father, husband, and friend, but also the great leader who never once turned his back on the American people.

To you, fellow guests, and the American people, I say God bless Joe Biden, God bless the country he served so devotedly, and God Bless the President.

To Joe, I say “yes we can”, and yes, you did.

`) //e.image = "" e.executable.push([2, (() => {e.image = e.image = 'https://itsastronomical.com/assets/2024/endings/obamafuneral.png'})]) } // Harris else if (quickstats[0] >= 270 && vp == 'walz') { e.pages.push(`

To Run or To Not Run | Walz in 2032?

Politico | September 19th, 2030

Vice President Tim Walz has, through it all, remained deeply loyal to President Kamala Harris and her agenda. Although the initial selection process was rushed for time, the two have had a good personal rapport and a friendship that has become far too uncommon in modern Presidential administrations. Harris has kept Walz involved and in the loop on practically every major decision she has made - from healthcare to foreign policy, and has taken his feedback into account.

With Harris bogged down hammering out a multilateral defense treaty in the Pacific - including Japan, South Korea, the Philippines, Australia, and New Zealand - the President has had little time to campaign during the midterms. She’s delegated much of it to Walz, and it appears to be paying off; The Cook Political Report has changed their rating in the open Pennsylvania’s Senate race, with 2024 runner-up Dave McCormick (R) and Congresswoman Susan Wild (D), from Tossup to Leans Democratic, likely giving Democrats a crucial hold and Pennsylvania’s first female Senator. Incumbents in other swing states - Michigan, Wisconsin, Nevada, and Arizona also appear to be in fairly comfortable positions as well, although many of them had razor-tight races in 2024 after polls showed them leading.

Still, there is a mutual doubt between the Harris and Walz camp about whether or not Mr. Walz should run in 2032 - although allies of both Harris and Walz have very different reasons for this decision.

In Kamalaworld, many of the top advisors to the President believe Mr. Walz - who would be almost 70 when he takes the oath of office, would be too old to run for and serve two full terms. The doubts many had over Biden’s age during his sole term has made this aspect especially important for the President. Meanwhile, Walz’s close confidants have doubts about whether or not he would be able to win - him being quite tied to a President with a 44% approval rating means that a 2032 campaign would be a steep climb.

Of course, Walz hasn’t closed the door completely on a Presidential campaign. Harris herself seems open to the idea, and if she asks him to run - perhaps with a pledge to serve one term, it’s highly likely he would do so.

Emerging from 2024 loss, Tim Walz holds a town hall in an Iowa Republican’s district

March 14th, 2025 | The Associated Press

DES MOINES, Iowa (AP) - Minnesota Gov. Tim Walz stood before hundreds of Iowans on Friday and admitted he doesn’t have all the answers about issues facing the country. “If I did, we wouldn’t be in this goddamn mess,” Walz said. Walz is back on the road to talk to voters, but he’s no longer a vice presidential candidate. He isn’t any kind of candidate, at least not for now. Walz is reemerging after last year’s election loss, granting interviews to national media and speaking to hundreds attending the Montana Democratic Party’s annual dinner earlier this month.

Now, he’s kicking off a tour of town halls in competitive congressional districts represented by Republicans, launched by a post on social media in response to guidance from House Speaker Mike Johnson that GOP representatives skip out on town halls, saying demonstrations outside of them were the work of “professional protesters.” “There’s a responsibility in this time of chaos where elected officials need to hear what people are irritated about,” Walz said. “And I would argue that Democratic officials should hear the primal scream that’s coming from America and do something.”

Walz said he wasn’t there to personally attack U.S. Rep. Zach Nunn, whose district includes the high school auditorium that nearly 1,000 people filled on Friday. But Walz called on Nunn to answer questions in public. Nunn won reelection in Iowa’s 3rd congressional district by about 4 percentage points in 2024, a margin of just under 16,000 voters. The Iowa Democratic Party got Walz’s call Monday evening and got to work planning the event Tuesday, said Paige Godden, the state party’s communications director. The crowd gave Walz a standing ovation. Many were wearing shirts with messages of political activism. A schoolteacher, a high school senior and a VA medical center worker asked Walz questions about health care, financial aid and funding for veterans.

He goes Saturday to Nebraska, where he grew up, with tentative stops to follow in Minnesota, Wisconsin and Ohio. The focus on Midwest neighbors and states in the Rust Belt isn’t a coincidence - many of them are places Walz didn’t visit during last year’s shortened campaign after Biden dropped out and made way for Vice President Kamala Harris atop the Democratic ticket. Walz passed on running for Senate next year but could be a contender for the 2028 presidential nomination. On 2024’s outcome, Walz said Democrats “need to acknowledge” that some voters didn’t see a difference between the Republican and Democratic presidential tickets and that the Democrats’ message on issues like immigration and Social Security didn’t resonate. He said he’s listening to learn why. Andrea Smith, a veteran, and her 19-year-old daughter, Liberty, said they were already going to be in Des Moines - about 120 miles from home in West Branch - to rally for veteran’s rights, and they decided to stay to see Walz.

“We related a lot to him,” Liberty Smith said. “He felt real during the election season.” Showing up to the Walz event was May Dehaan’s way of trying to get Nunn to notice that his constituents are frustrated. She wore a shirt that read: “This is not normal.”“Obviously, he’s not listening to his constituents. He’s following the GOP talking points.” said Dehaan, a retired interior designer from suburban Clive, who has herself written to Nunn. “We’re getting tired of being ignored.”

GOVERNOR AUSTIN DAVIS PROJECTED TO NARROWLY WIN FULL TERM

November 4th, 2026 | The Philadelphia Inquirer

Governor Austin Davis, who took office shortly after Josh Shapiro was elected Vice President of the United States, has narrowly been elected to a full term as Governor of Pennsylvania, defeating State Treasurer Stacy Garrity and becoming the first African-American Governor of the Commonwealth of Pennsylvania.

Governor Davis currently holds a 140,000 statewide margin, with some remaining votes in the suburbs of Philadelphia left to count. The margin currently stands at 50.3% of the vote for Mr. Davis, with 47.7% of the vote for Mrs. Garrity - a stark contrast to Mr. Shapiro's landslide margin four years prior.

It's not all bad news for Republicans - the party has appeared to have won back control of the State House of Representatives, held onto the State Senate, and flipped at least two Congressional District in the northeast - the 7th and 8th districts. Pennsylvania's 17th, a district comprising much of Pittsburgh's suburbs also is too close to call at this hour - incumbent Democrat Chris DeLuzio's lead has narrowed to under half a percentage and may continue to do so.

Although the election night was not perfect for Republicans, many believe that ousting Governor Davis was uncertain anyway, as he had "no firing offenses" according to one Republican strategist. Since taking office, Davis has laid low, continued Shapiro's bipartisan agenda, and steered clear of scandals and drama.

With such an uncontroversial Democrat only hanging on narrowly, many Republicans have now begun to salivate at the prospects of taking down Senator Fetterman in 2028. Fetterman has remained quite controversial with hardcore liberal Democratic constiuencies, and a portion of the grassroots seem interested in ousting him in a primary.

All the uncertainty here has top Republicans, both those in the state - such as Auditor DeFoor, York DA Dave Sunday, and those out of state - such as Senate Majority Leader John Thune - are waiting to see what unfolds during the primary process.

Governor Shapiro's Budget Proposal Sparks 2028 Discussions

January 2nd, 2027 | Pittsburgh Post-Gazette

Governor Shapiro has just put out an expansive budget proposal, seeking to use much of the surplus funds accumulated over the decade on a variety of public projects - ranging from repairing roads, funding school lunches, expanding the social safety net, and expanding the rollout of legal cannabis. Why?

One easy guess, and a theory shared by many of our political analysts - is that Shapiro is looking to pad out his resume ahead of any potential 2028 presidential bid, especially amongst progressive groups. Universal school lunches, cannabis reform, and social welfare expansions are near goals for progressives. Many voters who identified as progressive during the last presidential cycle showed low enthusiasm for the selection of Governor Shapiro as Harris' running mate. Although they aren't a voting bloc that Shapiro would need to secure the nomination, securing the goodwill of the left may make the difference between the White House and returning to Harrisburg come 2029.

With the new State Senate being 26-24 for the Democratic Party, and Shapiro's budget ambitions may be less farfetched than previous cycles. The State Senate Majority Leader, Jay Costa, has indicated he would give Shapiro significant input in the budget process given "the mandate voters have given him to bring us together". So too has the expanded State House majority for Democrats - at 111 House Dems to 92 House Republicans - signaled they would accept most of Shapiro's proposals. Speaker McClinton, who defied all odds and held onto her position in the 2024 elections, has said she would back Shapiro's budget proposals just as she did in 2023, 2024, 2025, and 2026.

Pennsylvania Democrats are clearly riding on a wave of enthusiasm and joy - it's the first time since 1993 they've held a trifecta in the state, and the first time since 1976 that voters have given them a full mandate to govern the state (the trifecta in 1993 was as a result of party switching).

Some potential concerns with the budget may play themselves out. Republicans, of course, are seemingly unified in their opposition to the proposal, while murmurs exist of a "rebellion" of Democratic lawmakers opposed to Shapiro's ambitions attempting to battle the budget in its current state.

Kelly Open To Harris Naming A New Vice President

CNN | January 2nd, 2028

Vice President Mark Kelly has told allies that while he is open to being Vice President for four more years, he has reportedly told President Kamala Harris that he is okay with her replacing him.

The decision comes following a vote late last year by the UAW (United Auto Workers) Union, who explicitly recommended that the President should name a new running mate but otherwise endorsed the administration and their actions involving labor.

While Vice President Kelly has been far from unpopular, his reputation with labor groups has continued to remain weak despite being the tie-breaking vote to pass the PRO Act last year.

Possible replacement VPs for the President largely follow two trains of thought. The first is a route of a caretaker running mate, one who has no intention of running for President in 2032. Possible contenders for this role include former North Carolina Governor Roy Cooper, former Wisconsin Governor Tony Evers and Minnesota Governor Tim Walz.

The other train of thought is to have Harris pick a running mate that could serve as an effective successor. Possible contenders here include Secretary of Transportation Pete Buttigieg and Maryland Governor Wes Moore.

Kirsten Sinema Is Making a Comeback, But Not in the Way Anyone Expected

Vox | August 3, 2026

What do a mechanic, a college student, an investment banker, and a naturalised farm worker have in common? You might think they couldn't be more different, but in Arizona, the answer is surprisingly simple.

This November, they're all going to vote for Kirsten Sinema.

It might be surprising to hear that the former Senator who held up much of the Biden Administration's legislation still has any political relevancy, but it seems that the social worker turned politician has tapped into an emerging source of political fortune.

"The technical term is syncretic populism," writes Danielle Alen, a political scientist from Harvard University. "It's something you see in countries where opportunities are limited and support for established governing institutions is low. Right now, many Americans want an outsider, but they want someone who can appeal to a variety of voters, and transcend the traditional left-right divide."

For Sinema, at least, it would seem that she fits this bill. Despite only launching her gubernatorial campaign a couple of months ago, a recent Ipsos poll put her at 31%, ahead of Republican Karrin Taylor Robson, and only a few points behind incumbent Katie Hobbs. And, in spite of both parties hurriedly funneling millions of dollars into the race, Sinema continues to gain ground.

In fact, according to some voters, increased advertising might actually be backfiring.

"You see a lot of campaign posters attacking Sinema now." says James Lopez, a resident of Phoenix and undecided voter. "But you go to one street corner, and you see one version of Sinema, and then you go to another street corner, and you see a completely different version of her. She hates immigrants, then she hates border security. She hates abortion, then she loves it. She wants to increase taxes, then she wants to cut them."

Whether these ads are working or not, Sinema remains unbowed, even going so far as to call out her rivals at a rally in Tuscon yesterday.

"You know, a lot of people who aren't from Arizona, who haven't even been to Arizona, are coming into this beautiful state and spreading lies. Lies about who I am, about what I stand for. So let me make this clear: I will not be controlled by Wall Street. I will not be controlled by the Californian Elite. I will not be controlled by the radical left and I will not be controlled by the radical right. The only people I will be controlled by are the voters and taxpayers of Arizona."

Whether or not the voters and taxpayers will stand with Sinema come November remains to be seen.

Vice President “harassed” by social media influencer Dan Hentschel

FOX News | April 24th, 2026

Vice President Dean Phillips has found himself the target of a new harassment campaign - or so he says. But it’s not a conservative grassroots movement pressuring him to break from President Harris’s big-government “New Way Forward” spending bill - it’s from an apolitical social media influencer, who says he just “wants to meet his hero”.

Dan Hentschel is a social media influencer with 500,000 subscribers on YouTube and 700,000 followers on 𝕏 (formerly known as Twitter). He is known for his absurdist comedy, making videos where he plays a variety of different roles, from a Target employee getting fired for an inappropriate post, to a therapist who hates his clients. His legal record, of course, isn’t the cleanest - Hentschel was investigated by police after making a post where he claimed he planned on shooting up his high school many years ago.

Lately, one of Dan Hentschel’s “storylines” as his fans call them has saw him grow desperate and desperate to meet with the Vice President, making numerous calls out through his posts, including painting himself blue because “Phillips is his hero!!!!!”, and asking his fans to tag the Vice President so he can be acknowledged.

Eventually, the Vice President decided to meet with him - or the two at least crossed paths at an event in Nevada. Hentschel had his blue paint on, and began to shake hands with the Vice President, before embracing him suddenly. Quickly, the Secret Service rushed in to rescue the Vice President, doing so by grabbing Mr. Hentschel before tasing him into the ground.

The Vice President spoke at the event, meant to be heard by the local culinary unions, where he claimed to have been “attacked” today by someone he presumed was “a fan”, and someone he had planned on meeting. Even some Hentschel fans believe he went too far, with some on social media saying that a line was crossed, with @ItsAstronomics on 𝕏 said that “Dan prolly crossed the line here, feels very weird to just hug someone you’ve never met like that.”

The White House has not commented on the event yet, other than stating that they are grateful the Vice President is safe and are coordinating with local law enforcement on the matter.

Former Harris Running Mate and Minnesota Rep. Phillips Launches Cryptocurrency

The Minnesota Star Tribune | July 1st, 2025

Former Minnesota Congressman and running mate to former Vice President Kamala Harris announced today that he would be launching a cryptocurrency called the 'CommonCent', because he claims that the use of cryptocurrency has become 'common sense'.

While Mr. Phillips is not the sole person involved in the launch of the currency, he has stated that he 'oversaw much of the process to confirm it's authenticity', and is 'eager to help build a community of fellow believers in 'CommonCents' values'.

The coin itself is expected to launch within the coming weeks - it comes after a series of rollbacks of Biden-era Crypto regulation by the Federal Trade Commission, causing some watchdog groups to worry about the use of crypto 'rugpull' scams by politicians.

'A lot of people trust politicians, so when they see this thing launch, this coin, many people buy in because these are they guys they like and voted for.', says Mark Scott of the newly formed Crypto Taskforce at Public Citizen, a consumer rights watchdog group. 'It was an issue with $TRUMP during his campaign, and it will likely be an issue with $DEAN or $CENTS or whatever he chooses to call it'.

LIVE: VICE PRESIDENT CASTRO TO RESIGN; RUN AGAINST PRESIDENT HARRIS IN THE PRIMARIES

September 16th, 2027 | The New York Times Staff

Vice President Joaquin Castro has formally notified President Kamala Harris and Secretary of State Liz Cheney of his intent to resign from the office of Vice President, in a shocking twist that raises the stakes of Castro's expected primary challenge to the President.

The resignation, so unprecedented in American history, represents Mr. Castro's desire to challenge the President in the primary process, citing 'irreconcilable differences' between him and the administration that 'prevented him from effectively carrying out the duties of the office of Vice President of the United States'.

While some have suggested that Mr. Castro is merely a stalking horse for a more serious nominee, the resignation of a Vice President in such a manner represents a serious blow to an administration's political power. Castro, however, does not appear to be the candidate to defeat Harris - a recent CNN poll found 55% of primary voters backing Harris, followed by 27% backing Castro. The remaining 18% of voters gave other answers or remain undecided.

In any case, getting a new Vice President through the evenly divided United States Senate, let alone keeping the Senate in order, seems to be an impossible task - Castro's resignation means that the 50 Democratic Senators and the 50 Republican Senators must form either some kind of power-sharing agreement in order to keep the chamber going. Senate Majority Leader Chuck Schumer has already called Democratic Senators back to Washington to figure something out.

The White House has not commented on the matter, but sources close to Harris expect some kind of address to be given over the next day or so.

`) //e.image = "" e.executable.push([2, (() => {e.image = e.image = 'https://itsastronomical.com/assets/2024/endings/castroresign.png'})]) } else if (quickstats[0] < 270 && vp == 'castro') { e.pages.push(`

OPINION: Biden Should Have Run For Re-election

Opinion Piece | The New York Times

The decision by President Joe Biden to not run a re-election campaign in the spring of 2023 was one that was seen as being focused on the 'long-term', putting aside personal ambition in favor of creating a field capable of defeating Donald Trump at the ballot box.

But Harris' loss to Donald Trump makes the logic behind the decision more confusing with hindsight.

Harris constistenly lagged behind Biden in approval ratings, only jumping ahead narrowly after securing the Democratic nomination in April of 2024. Many Americans could not argue how involved she was in the Biden administration's accomplishments, something crucial for any Democrat attempting to win the 2024 election.

Consider this - President Obama ran for re-election in 2012 despite a lagging economy and mixed approval ratings. He was able to secure a victory for two reasons - firstly, by being able to highlight the accomplishments that his administration made, and secondly, by painting his opponent as party of the reason why the recovery had not landed perfectly.

To an extent, Harris was able to perform the second - she hammered on Trump's COVID response and the threats that he poses to Democracy, but she could not paint a picture of a vision.

Harris was not involved in the Biden administration - but when she was, it was the worst jobs. 'Border Czar', as they called her, was the only real 'responsibility' given. She could not take credit for the Build Back Better plan, Student Loan relief, aid to Ukraine, or other Biden achievements, but she had to take the blame for his failures.

While Biden may have had some issues such as regarding his age, it's hard to see a world in which him running, with all his successes and failures, would have been a harder hill to climb than the one Harris had to.

`) //e.image = "" e.executable.push([2, (() => {e.image = e.image = 'https://itsastronomical.com/assets/2024/endings/bidendrops.png'})]) } else { /* Failsave */ e.pages.push(`

Read Barack Obama’s Eulogy for Joe Biden

June 6, 2027 | The New York Times

Former President Barack Obama on Sunday delivered a eulogy on behalf of President Joe Biden at a ceremony at the Holy Trinity Catholic Church, attended by many of Biden’s former colleagues and friends from Capitol Hill. The following is a transcript of those remarks, as prepared by The New York Times.

FORMER PRESIDENT BARACK OBAMA: To Joe’s loving family, to Jill, Hunter, Ashley, the many Biden grandchildren and great grandchildren, President Harris and First Gentleman Emhoff, Mrs. Trump, President and Mrs. Bush, President and Secretary Clinton, Vice President and Mrs. Pence, Vice President Gore, Vice President and Mrs. Quayle, and the friends, family, and colleagues both from within and outside Washington-

It is with great sadness that I am up here speaking today. Joe Biden was a man who devoted himself with utmost pride and fervor to anything he set out for. He was a loving husband, a devoted father, and by far the most diligent public servant I’ve ever had the pleasure of working with.

People forget - Joe and I were not always the perfect team. Before we shared a ticket we had been opponents. He helped shape us into the leaders we are - and he did so with the utmost respect, dignity, and pride. He did the same in the U.S. Senate, where he served for over 3 and a half decades, holding our government to the highest standard of leadership we could muster.

When I decided to ask him to join my ticket in 2008, I knew deep down that I was making the best decision I would make in my entire time as President. Joe Biden was in a league of his own - diligent, resilient, warm. He had invaluable experience that, to date, with no offence to my colleagues in attendance, makes him possibly one of the most overqualified Presidents to ever serve the office.

He and I were different, no doubt. There were many times where I found myself in awe at how easily he could speak to anyone, and how unwaveringly candid he was while doing so. There were times when he would speak up about things that even I found it hard to stand up for.

That really speaks to who Joe was as a leader. Those of us who knew him well knew even in his old age there was an unquenchable fire for justice, for doing the right thing. That fire fueled every decision he made as Senator, Vice President, and eventually as President. He wasn’t concerned about what made him the most electable - he was concerned with what was best for the American people. For anyone who has held this office or any office of leadership, you know - that’s a difficult position to be in. But Joe never wavered from what he thought was right.

In his time as Vice President, he and I have both often mentioned that he would be the last man in the room when making decisions. It’s the same relationship he would later have with his own Vice President. I can honestly say, those were some of the most important, and the most valuable moments of my Presidency. It was those moments that assured me not only that I’d made the right call in asking him to join my administration, but also that I had made a lifelong friend. For all the errors I made during my presidency - and heaven knows there’s plenty of folks out there who say I made a lot of them - I owe many of my successes and victories to his advice and support.

It’s the kind of wisdom that only comes from having been around the block a few times. Joe Biden had been in politics for longer than most of us here, had seen ten different administrations come and go during his political career. And in that time, Joe had overcome hardships that very few of us have had to face, and hopefully never will.

From the very start of his life as a public servant, Joe faced challenges. Before he could even be sworn in for the first time, he had to try and cope with the pain and grief of losing his wife Neilia and daughter Amy, and becoming a single father of two boys. Most people would have hit a wall right then and there, but not Joe. He managed to rise to being both a single dad and a Senator, and he never let himself drop the ball in either arena. That takes the kind of strength of character that only the best of us possess.

That strength didn’t just define who he was as a person but as a leader. He was grounded, in a way that a lot of us in Washington tend to lose touch from. He didn’t let partisan lines define people - he took a person at who they were, not their affiliation, and during his time in congress he managed to make countless friendships on both sides of the aisle, which you can tell just by the people in attendance here today. He believed in common decency, that the people in the other party weren’t your enemy, they just had different priorities. Through that, he did his best to serve not just the people who voted for him, but every American, to ensure no one felt left behind by their government.

Joe wasn’t the perfect man or the perfect leader, but he believed fiercely in the promise of America. He believed in standing by our allies, by our people, and by our values. Even in the rockiest moments of his career, he has had a fierce belief in the good of the American people. It was this belief that led to him running for President in 1988. It was what led him to join my ticket two decades later. It was this belief that helped him make the difficult decision to stand aside in 2016 - a decision to leave the fight to the rest of us while he spent a bit more time with his son Beau before he passed.

And when I say “fight,” let me be clear - I don’t mean fighting against another candidate or party. I mean the fight for the American people. Joe didn’t believe in “us vs. them”. He believed in “us and them”. That’s why he decided to come back and run again in 2020 - so he could start bringing the people together. Because he knew better than most that a united front is the only way through a crisis.

Y’know, Joe didn’t outright say it much, but he took a lot of inspiration from his predecessors when making decisions. Not me, of course - he learnt a lot more from my screw ups, I think. But there were other Presidents, like Kennedy or Lyndon Johnson, that he really aspired to. I think he was most inspired by Franklin Roosevelt, as evidenced by the portrait he kept over the fireplace in the oval. Anyone who takes up the mantle of the presidency knows he or she has big shoes to fill, and all of us want to leave a legacy that lives up to the greats.

Not all of us can live up to that legacy, and not all of us are remembered for what we want to be remembered for - don’t I know - but I think in Joe’s case, he’d be proud of the legacy he’s leaving behind. He may not have done it with the same pomp as some of our fellow presidents, but I know that when I think of his time in office, I will remember how he pulled us out of the depths of a pandemic and left us with rock solid support to our economy, workforce, military, and country. In that way, I can honestly say that Joe lived up to the legacies that he had once aspired to.

So when I remember Joe Biden, I’ll not only think of the loving father, husband, and friend, but also the great leader who never once turned his back on the American people.

To you, fellow guests, and the American people, I say God bless Joe Biden, God bless the country he served so devotedly, and God Bless the President.

To Joe, I say “yes we can”, and yes, you did.

`) //e.image = "" e.executable.push([2, (() => {e.image = e.image = 'https://itsastronomical.com/assets/2024/endings/obamafuneral.png'})]) } // Page 4 - Gaza // These are all poems written by Palestinian poets. Originally this page was your usual news article, but after some thinking, I felt it was more appropriate to include poetry instead. I realized that doing American-centric news articles would be insensitive and would essentially be "Americanizing" the tragedy and taking the voice of actual people involved in the conflict. // I hope you all can understand, and can appreciate this art. Also Free Palestine // Regional War if (gaza == -3) { e.pages.push(`

If I Must Die

by Refaat Alareer (1979–2023)

If I must die,
you must live
to tell my story
to sell my things
to buy a piece of cloth
and some strings,
(make it white with a long tail)
so that a child, somewhere in Gaza
while looking heaven in the eye
awaiting his dad who left in a blaze —
and bid no one farewell
not even to his flesh
not even to himself —
sees the kite, my kite you made, flying up above,
and thinks for a moment an angel is there
bringing back love.
If I must die
let it bring hope,
let it be a story.

Refaat Alareer (1979–2023) was a professor of world literature and creative writing at the Islamic University of Gaza and the editor of Gaza Writes Back: Short Stories from Young Writers in Gaza, Palestine (2013). He was killed by an IDF airstrike on December 6, 2023, along with his brother, nephew, his sister, and three of her children.

`) //e.image = "" e.executable.push([3, (() => {e.image = e.image = 'https://itsastronomical.com/assets/2024/endings/ifimustdie.png'})]) } // Stable Ceasefire else if (gaza >= 2) { ctsAchievement("Cease With Honor"); e.pages.push(`

Hope

by Mahmoud Darwish (1941–2008)

We have an incurable malady: hope.
Hope in liberation and independence.
Hope in a normal life where we are neither heroes nor victims.
Hope that our children will go safely to their schools.
Hope that a pregnant woman will give birth to a living baby at the hospital, and not a dead child in front of a military checkpoint;
hope that our poets will see the beauty of the colour red in roses rather than in blood;
hope that this land will take up its original name: the land of love and peace.

Mahmoud Darwish (1941–2008) was a Palestinian poet and author. He is regarded as one of the most significant poets in modern Palestinian history. Among other things, in 1988, he wrote the Palestinian Declaration of Independence, which was ratified by the Palestinian Liberation Organization. He passed away in 2008 from complications following a heart surgery. This short poem was written in 2002.

`) //e.image = "" e.executable.push([3, (() => {e.image = e.image = 'https://itsastronomical.com/assets/2024/endings/flags.png'})]) } // Uneasy Ceasefire, but it holds else if (gaza == 1 && held == true) { e.pages.push(`

I Belong There

by Mahmoud Darwish (1941–2008)

I belong there. I have many memories. I was born as everyone is born.
I have a mother, a house with many windows, brothers, friends, and a prison cell
with a chilly window! I have a wave snatched by seagulls, a panorama of my own.
I have a saturated meadow. In the deep horizon of my word, I have a moon,
a bird’s sustenance, and an immortal olive tree.
I have lived on the land long before swords turned man into prey.
I belong there. When heaven mourns for her mother, I return heaven to her mother.
And I cry so that a returning cloud might carry my tears.
To break the rules, I have learned all the words needed for a trial by blood.
I have learned and dismantled all the words in order to draw from them a
single word: Home.

Mahmoud Darwish (1941–2008) was a Palestinian poet and author. He is regarded as one of the most significant poets in modern Palestinian history. Among other things, in 1988, he wrote the Palestinian Declaration of Independence, which was ratified by the Palestinian Liberation Organization. He passed away in 2008 from complications following a heart surgery.

`) //e.image = "" e.executable.push([3, (() => {e.image = e.image = 'https://itsastronomical.com/assets/2024/endings/belong.png'})]) } // Uneasy Ceasefire, allow it to break else if (gaza == 1 && held == false) { e.pages.push(`

Enough for Me

by Fadwa Tuqan (1917-2003)

Enough for me to die on her earth
be buried in her
to melt and vanish into her soil
then sprout forth as a flower
played with by a child from my country.

Enough for me to remain
in my country’s embrace
to be in her close as a handful of dust
a sprig of grass
a flower.

Fadwa Tuqan (1917-2003) was a Palestinian poet from the West Bank. One of her brother, Ibrahim Tuqan was also a poet. She wrote extensively about Israel's occupation of Palestine, and passed away from natural causes during the height of the Second Intifada.

`) //e.image = "" e.executable.push([3, (() => {e.image = e.image = 'https://itsastronomical.com/assets/2024/endings/flower.png'})]) } // Win the election, but no ceasefire else if (quickstats[0] >= 270 && gaza <= 0) { e.pages.push(`

Carob Tree

by Tariq Alarabi

I want to talk with you. It’s been a while
since anyone’s talked with me, no one around
says to me the things I say to you
when I’m sleepwalking.
For example, yesterday at 3AM the soldiers rained
tear gas bombs on us, ten workers
who crammed in a walk-in refrigerator for produce.
And the gas, like crude oil
that spilled into sea,
a forest fire that occupied all the air.
The carob tree was uprooted.
I still don’t know what you’re like
when you catch the flu.
Tomatoes are cheap this season
and the farmers are sad.
I’ve saved the best tomatoes for you.
As for the first thing I do when I wake up
I check the weather.
Weather enthusiasts in Palestine, like followers
of skincare products on Instagram,
are many.
And one more thing, since you’re not here
do you like eggplant?

Tariq Alarabi is a poet in Nablus, a city in the West Bank region of Palestine.

`) //e.image = "" e.executable.push([3, (() => {e.image = e.image = 'https://itsastronomical.com/assets/2024/endings/trees.png'})]) } // Lose the election to Trump, and no ceasefire else if (quickstats[0] < 270 && (campaignTrail_temp.candidate_json[2]["fields"].last_name == "Trump" || campaignTrail_temp.candidate_json[2]["fields"].last_name == "Trump (POW)") && gaza <= 0) { e.pages.push(`

Oh Rascal Children Of Gaza

by Khaled Juma (b. 1964)

Oh rascal children of Gaza,
You who constantly disturbed me with your screams under my window,
You who filled every morning with rush and chaos,
You who broke my vase and stole the lonely flower on my balcony,
Come back –
and some strings,
And scream as you want,
And break all the vases,
Steal all the flowers,
Come back,
Just come back…

Khaled Juma (b. 1964) is a writer from Palestine. Oh Rascal Children Of Gaza was written during the 2014 Gaza War, which resulted in over 2,000 deaths - mainly civillians.

`) //e.image = "" e.executable.push([3, (() => {e.image = e.image = 'https://itsastronomical.com/assets/2024/endings/gazasunset.png'})]) } // Lose the election to other Republicans, and no ceasefire else { e.pages.push(`

I Grant You Refuge

by Hiba Abu Nada (1991-2023)

1.
I grant you refuge
in invocation and prayer.
I bless the neighborhood and the minaret
to guard them
from the rocket
from the moment
it is a general’s command
until it becomes
a raid.
I grant you and the little ones refuge,
the little ones who
change the rocket’s course
before it lands
with their smiles.
2.
I grant you and the little ones refuge,
the little ones now asleep like chicks in a nest.
They don’t walk in their sleep toward dreams.
They know death lurks outside the house.
Their mothers’ tears are now doves
following them, trailing behind
every coffin.
3.
I grant the father refuge,
the little ones’ father who holds the house upright
when it tilts after the bombs.
He implores the moment of death:
“Have mercy. Spare me a little while.
For their sake, I’ve learned to love my life.
Grant them a death
as beautiful as they are.”
4.
I grant you refuge
from hurt and death,
refuge in the glory of our siege,
here in the belly of the whale.
Our streets exalt God with every bomb.
They pray for the mosques and the houses.
And every time the bombing begins in the North,
our supplications rise in the South.
5.
I grant you refuge
from hurt and suffering.
With words of sacred scripture
I shield the oranges from the sting of phosphorous
and the shades of cloud from the smog.
I grant you refuge in knowing
that the dust will clear,
and they who fell in love and died together
will one day laugh.

Hiba Abu Nada (1991-2023) was a novelist, educator, and poet. She was killed in her home in South Gaza by an Israeli raid on October 20th, 2023.

`) //e.image = "" e.executable.push([3, (() => {e.image = e.image = 'https://itsastronomical.com/assets/2024/endings/refuge.png'})]) } // Page 5 - AmericanHistoryUSA if (running == false && campaignTrail_temp.candidate_json[2]["fields"].last_name == "Trump" && campaignTrail_temp.candidate_json[0]["fields"].last_name == "Harris") { // Trump/Harris (Clean Exit) e.pages.push(`

    American History USA

    THE CAMPAIGN TRAIL

    Please select the election you will run in:


    The earth-shattering withdrawl of President Joe Biden and the arrest of former President Donald Trump has left both parties largely leaderless. The Republican National Convention has nominated Trump's namesake, Donald Trump Jr. to lead the party and the Presidential ticket.

    Meanwhile, Vice President Kamala Harris has been called upon by her party to lead them out of this crisis. Can she make the case to voters that the era of Trump is over? Can Trump Jr. keep the emotions high into election day?


    `) e.executable.push([4, (() => {e.image = e.image = 'https://i.imgur.com/y4eg352.png'})]) } else if (campaignTrail_temp.candidate_json[2]["fields"].last_name == "Trump Jr." && campaignTrail_temp.candidate_json[0]["fields"].last_name == "Biden") { // Trump Jr./Biden e.pages.push(`

    American History USA

    THE CAMPAIGN TRAIL

    Please select the election you will run in:


    The 2024 election was thrown off the rails as former President Donald Trump was arrested and sentenced to time in prison. A Republican National Convention resembling a funeral has nominated Trump's namesake, Donald Trump Jr. to lead the party and the Presidential ticket.

    Biden has been struggling in the polls for awhile, but some advisors believe this crisis has changed the dynamics of the election, perhaps to his benefit. Can Biden turn things around? Can Trump Jr. keep the emotions high into election day?


    `) e.executable.push([4, (() => {e.image = e.image = 'https://i.imgur.com/y4eg352.png'})]) } else if (campaignTrail_temp.candidate_json[2]["fields"].last_name == "Haley" && campaignTrail_temp.candidate_json[0]["fields"].last_name == "Harris") { // Haley/Harris e.pages.push(`

    Biden has been struggling in the polls for awhile, but some advisors believe this crisis has changed the dynamics of the election, perhaps to his benefit. Can Biden turn things around? Can Burgum forge a new path for his Grand Old Party?

By some bizarre series of events, independent candidate Robert Kennedy Jr. secured the GOP mantle after a chaotic convention gone haywire.

    Biden has been struggling in the polls for awhile, but some advisors believe this crisis has changed the dynamics of the election, perhaps to his benefit. Can Biden turn things around? Can Robert Kennedy Jr. unite the opposition against the Democratic Party?


    `) e.executable.push([4, (() => {e.image = e.image = 'https://i.imgur.com/y4eg352.png'})]) } else if (campaignTrail_temp.candidate_json[2]["fields"].last_name == "Trump (POW)" && campaignTrail_temp.candidate_json[0]["fields"].last_name == "Harris") { // Trump/Harris e.pages.push(`

    American History USA

    THE CAMPAIGN TRAIL

    Please select the election you will run in:


    A rocky four years under President Biden have culminated in former President Donald Trump's nomination while serving under house arrest, followed by the earth-shaking withdrawal of Joe Biden from the race.

  • Donald Trump, running his campaign while under house arrest, only seems to trail Harris very narrowly. Can he keep his momentum going all the way through Election Day? Is the momentum even real?
  • Kamala Harris assumed the Democratic nomination with the strong support of President Biden. She enters the general election rested and ready, riding a surge of enthusiasm and record fundraising.

    • `) e.executable.push([4, (() => {e.image = e.image = 'https://i.imgur.com/y4eg352.png'})]) } else if (campaignTrail_temp.candidate_json[2]["fields"].last_name == "Trump (POW)" && campaignTrail_temp.candidate_json[0]["fields"].last_name == "Biden") { // Trump/Biden e.pages.push(`

    American History USA

    THE CAMPAIGN TRAIL

    Please select the election you will run in:


    The 2024 election feels like a familiar sight to the American voter. But much has changed, and pundits on both sides are claiming that the fate of American democracy is on the line.

  • Joe Biden enters the final stretch of the campaign with dismal approvals, low enthusiasm, and persistent concerns about age. However, he has the upper hand on trust and values issues.
  • Donald Trump, running his campaign while under house arrest, seems unusually competitive. Can he keep his momentum going all the way through Election Day? Is the momentum even real?

    • `) e.executable.push([4, (() => {e.image = e.image = 'https://i.imgur.com/y4eg352.png'})]) } return construct(0); } e = campaignTrail_temp; // State of Play in Washington // Shows you who is in what position campaignTrail_temp.advisors = [ { pk: 5000, role: "Speaker of the House of Representatives", }, { pk: 5001, role: "Leading Republican Opponent", }, { pk: 5002, role: "Factional Opposition", }, { pk: 5003, role: "United States Attorney General", } ]; // updateAdvisor(5000, "Vacant", "https://itsastronomical.com/assets/2024/opp/vacant.png", "NOW: MCCARTHY APPEARS TO SUFFER DEFEAT ON FIRST SPEAKER BALLOT"); // updateAdvisor(5000, "Kevin McCarthy", "https://itsastronomical.com/assets/2024/opp/mccarthy.png", "Has yearned for decades for this position. Is it worth it?"); // updateAdvisor(5000, "Brian Fitzpatrick", "https://itsastronomical.com/assets/2024/opp/fitz.png", "How did this sucker get here? Who knows. He won't be around long, however."); // updateAdvisor(5000, "Mike Johnson", "https://itsastronomical.com/assets/2024/opp/johnson.png", "They call him the Origami Speaker. He folds nonstop for the right wing — and for you."); // updateAdvisor(5000, "Tom Emmer", "https://itsastronomical.com/assets/2024/opp/emmer.png", "For what it's worth, Trump denounced his bid for the position from the get-go."); // updateAdvisor(5000, "Patrick McHenry", "https://itsastronomical.com/assets/2024/opp/mchenry.png", "The Speaker Pro Tempore is no longer here just ''for the time being.''"); // updateAdvisor(5000, "Hakeem Jeffries", "https://itsastronomical.com/assets/2024/opp/jeffries.png", "Working on major, bipartisan reform to the House so they can supply Ukraine and Israel with more ammunition."); // updateAdvisor(5001, "Donald Trump Jr.", "https://itsastronomical.com/assets/2024/opp/donjr.png", "Donald Trump's namesake. But not his first choice for Crown Prince."); // updateAdvisor(5001, "Nikki Haley", "https://itsastronomical.com/assets/2024/opp/haley.png", "Trump calls her 'Birdbrain'. Ignore the fact she was in his administration."); // updateAdvisor(5001, "Ron DeSantis", "https://itsastronomical.com/assets/2024/opp/desantis.png", "Governor of Florida. Fighting wokeism, one book burning at a time."); // updateAdvisor(5001, "JD Vance", "https://itsastronomical.com/assets/2024/opp/vance.png", "Sold his soul just for the chance to be here. Hopes he's making his meemaw proud."); // updateAdvisor(5001, "Doug Burgum", "https://itsastronomical.com/assets/2024/opp/burgum.png", "How he managed to get here remains a mystery. Even he's amazed by it."); // updateAdvisor(5001, "P01135809", "https://itsastronomical.com/assets/2024/opp/trumpjail.png", "Donald J. Trump, 45th President of the United States. Hopes to break the glass ceiling and become the first convicted felon elected President."); // updateAdvisor(5001, "Robert Kennedy Jr.", "https://itsastronomical.com/assets/2024/opp/rfk.png", "The GOP must have truly lost their way if they're running a fucking Kennedy - not only that, but possibly the worst one."); // updateAdvisor(5001, "Grok", "https://itsastronomical.com/assets/2024/opp/grok.png", "Trained on Truth Social posts and Fox News transcripts. Believes it's the real Trump — and honestly, it may as well be."); // updateAdvisor(5002, "Robert Kennedy Jr.", "https://itsastronomical.com/assets/2024/opp/rfk.png", "Him running is as annoying as his voice. As scandalous as one would expect from a Kennedy."); // updateAdvisor(5002, "Jill Stein", "https://itsastronomical.com/assets/2024/opp/stein.png", "Greatest ally of the left, Vladimir Putin, and the Republican National Convention."); // updateAdvisor(5002, "Dean Phillips", "https://itsastronomical.com/assets/2024/opp/phillips.png", "Also known as Dean Quixote. Some people have too much money."); // updateAdvisor(5002, "Panic", "https://itsastronomical.com/assets/2024/opp/panic.png", "Perhaps America as a whole has the morals of an Alley Cat."); // updateAdvisor(5002, "Unburdened", "https://itsastronomical.com/assets/2024/opp/unburdened.png", "It's time to imagine what can be, unburdened by what has been."); // updateAdvisor(5003, "Merrick Garland", "https://itsastronomical.com/assets/2024/opp/garland.png", "Finally given his due. Let's hope he can make this one count."); // updateAdvisor(5003, "Doug Jones", "https://itsastronomical.com/assets/2024/opp/jones.png", "Singlehandedly keeping the mean IQ of Alabama above 80, which isn’t an easy task."); // updateAdvisor(5003, "Deval Patrick", "https://itsastronomical.com/assets/2024/opp/patrick.png", "Obama. Obama. Obama. It's crazy how far a single name can get you in politics."); // Define possible opponents and their conditions const opponents = [ { name: "Robert Kennedy Jr.", picture: "https://itsastronomical.com/assets/2024/opp/rfk.png", advice: "The GOP must have truly lost their way if they're running a fucking Kennedy - not only that, but possibly the worst one.", condition: () => bobby >= 1, priority: () => (bobby >= 1 ? 1 : 0) }, { name: "JD Vance", picture: "https://itsastronomical.com/assets/2024/opp/vance.png", advice: "Sold his soul just for the chance to be here. Hopes he's making his meemaw proud.", condition: () => wins >= 4 && gaza >= 2, priority: () => (wins >= 4 ? 1 : 0) + (gaza >= 2 ? 1 : 0) }, { name: "Nikki Haley", picture: "https://itsastronomical.com/assets/2024/opp/haley.png", advice: "Trump calls her 'Birdbrain'. Ignore the fact she was in his administration.", condition: () => wins >= 4 && gaza <= 1, priority: () => (wins >= 4 ? 1 : 0) + (gaza < 2 ? 1 : 0) }, { name: "Ron DeSantis", picture: "https://itsastronomical.com/assets/2024/opp/desantis.png", advice: "Governor of Florida. Fighting wokeism, one book burning at a time.", condition: () => wins < 4 && gaza >= 2, priority: () => (wins < 4 ? 1 : 0) + (gaza >= 2 ? 1 : 0) }, { name: "Doug Burgum", picture: "https://itsastronomical.com/assets/2024/opp/burgum.png", advice: "How he managed to get here remains a mystery. Even he's amazed by it.", condition: () => wins < 4 && gaza <= 1, priority: () => (wins < 4 ? 1 : 0) + (gaza < 2 ? 1 : 0) } ]; // Function to select the closest opponent function selectClosestOpponent() { if (bobby >= 1) { return opponents.find(o => o.name === "Robert Kennedy Jr."); } let closestOpponent = null; let highestPriority = -1; for (let opponent of opponents) { let priority = opponent.priority(); if (priority > highestPriority) { highestPriority = priority; closestOpponent = opponent; } } // Default opponent if no conditions are met if (!closestOpponent) { closestOpponent = { name: "Donald Trump Jr.", picture: "https://itsastronomical.com/assets/2024/opp/donjr.png", advice: "Donald Trump's namesake. But not his first choice for Crown Prince." }; } return closestOpponent; } // Update the advisor based on the closest opponent function updateLeadingRepublicanOpponent() { const opponent = selectClosestOpponent(); updateAdvisor(5001, opponent.name, opponent.picture, opponent.advice); } campaignTrail_temp.advice = [ { advisor_pk: 5000, name: "Nancy Pelosi", picture: "https://itsastronomical.com/assets/2024/opp/pelosi.png", advice: "Tormented Trump for two years. Eager to shepherd your agenda." }, { advisor_pk: 5001, name: "Donald Trump", picture: "https://itsastronomical.com/assets/2024/trump.png", advice: "Runner-up in 2020, though he's too egoistical to ever admit that." }, { advisor_pk: 5002, name: "Virtually None", picture: "https://itsastronomical.com/assets/2024/opp/unity.png", advice: "Keep this up, and who knows what is possible? Keep in mind a coalition can fall apart easily..." }, { advisor_pk: 5003, name: "Jeffery A. Rosen", picture: "https://itsastronomical.com/assets/2024/opp/rosen.png", advice: "Trump's Executive Government remains a revolving door." } ]; function updateAdvisor(advisor_pk, newName, newPicture, newAdvice) { let advice = campaignTrail_temp.advice.find(a => a.advisor_pk === advisor_pk); if (advice) { advice.name = newName; advice.picture = newPicture; advice.advice = newAdvice; } else { console.error(`No advice found for advisor_pk: ${advisor_pk}`); } } function addHQButton() { // Check if the button already exists if (document.getElementById('headquarter_button')) { return; } // Find the reference button by its ID const refButton = document.getElementById('view_electoral_map'); if (!refButton) { return; } // Create a new button element const newButton = document.createElement('button'); newButton.id = 'headquarter_button'; newButton.style.marginLeft = '1.5em'; newButton.innerHTML = 'State of the Union ⚖️'; // Attach the click event listener newButton.addEventListener('click', openHQ); // Insert the new button next to the reference button refButton.insertAdjacentElement('afterend', newButton); } function openHQ() { // Update the leading Republican opponent if (altprimary == true) { updateLeadingRepublicanOpponent(); } let questions = document.querySelector(".inner_window_question"); questions.style.display = 'none'; const hqButton = document.getElementById('headquarter_button'); if (hqButton) { hqButton.remove(); } // Create and set up the headquarters div let hqDiv = document.createElement('div'); hqDiv.id = 'headquarter'; hqDiv.style.display = 'flex'; // Set layout to flex to allow columns hqDiv.style.color = 'white'; // hqDiv.style.backgroundColor = '#383838'; hqDiv.style.backgroundImage = 'url(https://itsastronomical.com/assets/2024/potusoffice.png)'; // Set background image. I would recommend using the same file size as the original image, ~959 x 327. Otherwise it will stretch the image. Comment or remove this line of text if you don't want a background image and instead want hqDiv.style.backgroundColor to set your background color hqDiv.style.border = '5px solid white'; hqDiv.style.borderRadius = '10px'; hqDiv.style.height = '53%'; hqDiv.style.flexDirection = 'column'; hqDiv.style.alignItems = 'center'; // Create header div let headerDiv = document.createElement('div'); headerDiv.style.display = 'flex'; headerDiv.style.justifyContent = 'space-between'; headerDiv.style.width = '100%'; headerDiv.style.alignItems = 'center'; // Add back button to the header let backButton = document.createElement('button'); backButton.innerText = 'Back'; backButton.style.margin = '5px'; backButton.style.backgroundColor = 'grey'; backButton.style.position = 'absolute'; backButton.style.top = '95px'; backButton.style.left = '20px'; backButton.onclick = function() { // Hide headquarters and show the original content hqDiv.remove(); questions.style.display = ''; } headerDiv.appendChild(backButton); // Create h3 element for the header let headerText = document.createElement('h2'); headerText.textContent = 'State of the Union'; headerText.style.textAlign = 'center'; // Center the text headerText.style.flexGrow = '1'; // Make h3 take up the maximum space available headerDiv.appendChild(headerText); // Append headerDiv to the main hqDiv hqDiv.appendChild(headerDiv); // Create a container div for both columns let columnsDiv = document.createElement('div'); columnsDiv.style.display = 'flex'; columnsDiv.style.width = '100%'; // Create inner divs for columns let leftCol = document.createElement('div'); leftCol.style.width = '50%'; columnsDiv.appendChild(leftCol); let rightCol = document.createElement('div'); rightCol.style.width = '50%'; columnsDiv.appendChild(rightCol); // Append columnsDiv to the main hqDiv hqDiv.appendChild(columnsDiv); var roles = [ { role: 'Speaker of the House', pk: 5000 }, { role: 'Leading Republican Opponent', pk: 5001 }, { role: 'Factional Opposition', pk: 5002 }, { role: 'United States Attorney General', pk: 5003 } ]; for (let i = 0; i < roles.length; i++) { let roleInfo = roles[i]; let advice = campaignTrail_temp.advice.find(a => a.advisor_pk === roleInfo.pk); if (!advice) { console.error(`No advice found for advisor_pk: ${roleInfo.pk}`); continue; } let advisorDiv = document.createElement('div'); advisorDiv.style.height = '7.5em'; advisorDiv.style.padding = '1em'; advisorDiv.style.display = 'flex'; advisorDiv.style.marginBottom = '1em'; // Image let img = document.createElement('img'); img.src = advice.picture; img.style.height = '100%'; img.style.marginRight = '1em'; img.style.border = '1px solid white'; // Add thin white border to the image // Description let descriptionDiv = document.createElement('div'); descriptionDiv.style.display = 'flex'; descriptionDiv.style.flexDirection = 'column'; descriptionDiv.style.justifyContent = 'center'; let role = document.createElement('h5'); role.textContent = roleInfo.role; role.style.margin = '3px'; descriptionDiv.appendChild(role); let name = document.createElement('h3'); name.textContent = advice.name; name.style.margin = '3px'; descriptionDiv.appendChild(name); let bio = document.createElement('p'); bio.textContent = advice.advice; bio.style.margin = '3px'; descriptionDiv.appendChild(bio); advisorDiv.appendChild(img); advisorDiv.appendChild(descriptionDiv); // Append advisorDiv to the appropriate column if (i % 2 === 0) { leftCol.appendChild(advisorDiv); } else { rightCol.appendChild(advisorDiv); } } questions.parentNode.insertBefore(hqDiv, questions.nextSibling); } // Variable HQ function addHeadquarterButton() { // Check if the button already exists if (document.getElementById('hq_button')) { return; } // Find the reference button by its ID const refButton = document.getElementById('view_electoral_map'); if (!refButton) { return; } // Create a new button element const newButton = document.createElement('button'); newButton.id = 'hq_button'; newButton.style.marginLeft = '1.5em'; newButton.innerHTML = 'Campaign Data 📜'; // Attach the click event listener newButton.addEventListener('click', openHeadquarter); // Insert the new button next to the Headquarters button const headquarterButton = document.getElementById('headquarter_button'); if (headquarterButton) { headquarterButton.insertAdjacentElement('afterend', newButton); } else { refButton.insertAdjacentElement('afterend', newButton); } } function openHeadquarter() { if (trust >= 5) { trustText = 'a high degree of trust' } if (trust >= 3 && trust < 5) { trustText = 'a moderate amount of trust' } if (trust < 3) { trustText = 'little to no trust' } if (leftrep >= 4) { leftText = 'surprisingly enthusiastic about' } if (leftrep >= 1 && leftrep < 4) { leftText = 'be warming up to' } if (leftrep < 1) { leftText = 'have low opinions of' } if (gaza == 2) { gazaText = 'a hopeful ceasefire.' } if (gaza == 1) { gazaText = 'an uncertain ceasefire.' } if (gaza == 0) { gazaText = 'quieter today than it has been in two decades.' } if (gaza == -1) { gazaText = 'an outright conflict.' } if (gaza == -2) { gazaText = 'being made worse by the United States.' } if (gaza == -3) { gazaText = 'a full-on regional war.' } if (loyalty >= 3) { loyaltyText = 'No Daylight, Kid' } if (loyalty >= 1 && loyalty < 3) { loyaltyText = 'somewhat high' } if (loyalty == 0) { loyaltyText = 'pretty average' } if (loyalty < -1 && loyalty >= -3) { loyaltyText = 'somewhat low' } if (loyalty < -3) { loyaltyText = 'disloyal' } let questions = document.querySelector(".inner_window_question"); questions.style.display = 'none'; const hq_Button = document.getElementById('hq_button'); if (hq_Button) { hq_Button.remove(); } // Create and set up the headquarters div let hqDiv = document.createElement('div'); hqDiv.id = 'headquarter'; hqDiv.style.display = 'flex'; // Set layout to flex to allow columns hqDiv.style.color = 'white'; hqDiv.style.backgroundColor = '#383838'; hqDiv.style.backgroundImage = 'url(https://itsastronomical.com/assets/2024/potusoffice.png)'; // Set background image. I would recommend using the same file size as the original image, ~959 x 327. Otherwise it will stretch the image. Comment or remove this line of text if you don't want a background image and instead want hqDiv.style.backgroundColor to set your background color hqDiv.style.border = '5px solid black'; hqDiv.style.borderRadius = '10px'; hqDiv.style.height = '53%'; hqDiv.style.flexDirection = 'column'; hqDiv.style.alignItems = 'center'; hqDiv.style.position = 'relative'; // Create header div let headerDiv = document.createElement('div'); headerDiv.style.display = 'flex'; headerDiv.style.justifyContent = 'space-between'; headerDiv.style.width = '100%'; headerDiv.style.alignItems = 'center'; let headerText = document.createElement('h2'); headerText.innerHTML = 'Chief of Staff - Campaign Data'; headerText.style.textAlign = 'center'; // Center the text headerText.style.flexGrow = '1'; // Make h3 take up the maximum space available headerDiv.appendChild(headerText); // Append headerDiv to the main hqDiv hqDiv.appendChild(headerDiv); // Create a container div for both columns let columnsDiv = document.createElement('div'); columnsDiv.style.display = 'flex'; columnsDiv.style.width = '100%'; // Create inner divs for columns let leftCol = document.createElement('div'); leftCol.style.width = '50%'; columnsDiv.appendChild(leftCol); let rightCol = document.createElement('div'); rightCol.style.width = '50%'; columnsDiv.appendChild(rightCol); // Append columnsDiv to the main hqDiv hqDiv.appendChild(columnsDiv); questions.parentNode.insertBefore(hqDiv, questions.nextSibling); // This is the bulk of the content you can edit. You can add more text or images here. // Create Bulk of the Text // Duplicate this section to add more lines of text. Make sure to change the variable name "a" to something else. In this case, I changed it to "b". let a = document.createElement('p'); a.innerHTML = 'You have achieved ' + wins + ' legislative and/or policy successes.'; // This is the text that will be displayed. You can change this to whatever you want. ' + function + ' will display the number from the function. // a.style.flexGrow = '0.1'; // Make h3 take up the maximum space available a.style.color = 'white'; // Can be used to change the color of the text a.style.margin = '5px'; // Can be used to change the space in between the text. Useful if you have a lot of functions. hqDiv.appendChild(a); let b = document.createElement('p'); b.innerHTML = 'The American people seem to have ' + trustText + ' in the Biden/Harris administration. (' + trust + ')'; // b.style.flexGrow = '0.1'; // Make h3 take up the maximum space available b.style.color = 'white'; b.style.margin = '5px'; hqDiv.appendChild(b); let c = document.createElement('p'); c.innerHTML = 'Progressives seem to ' + leftText + ' the Biden/Harris administration. (' + leftrep + ')'; // c.style.flexGrow = '0.1'; // Make h3 take up the maximum space available c.style.color = 'white'; c.style.margin = '5px'; hqDiv.appendChild(c); let d = document.createElement('p'); d.innerHTML = 'The situation in the Middle East is ' + gazaText + ' (' + gaza + ')'; // d.style.flexGrow = '0.1'; // Make h3 take up the maximum space available d.style.color = 'white'; d.style.margin = '5px'; hqDiv.appendChild(d); if (dropout == true) { let e = document.createElement('p'); e.innerHTML = 'Kamala Harris’ loyalty to President Biden is ' + loyaltyText + ' (' + loyalty + ')'; // d.style.flexGrow = '0.1'; // Make h3 take up the maximum space available e.style.color = 'white'; e.style.margin = '5px'; hqDiv.appendChild(e); } // Image let img = document.createElement('img'); img.src = 'https://itsastronomical.com/assets/2024/dembanner.png'; img.style.height = '30%'; img.style.marginLeft = '1em'; img.style.flexGrow = '0.1'; img.style.border = '3px solid black'; // Add thin white border to the image hqDiv.appendChild(img); // Add back button to the header let backButton = document.createElement('button'); backButton.innerText = 'Back'; backButton.style.margin = '5px'; backButton.style.backgroundColor = 'grey'; backButton.style.position = 'absolute'; backButton.style.top = '16px'; backButton.style.left = '10px'; backButton.onclick = function() { // Hide headquarters and show the original content hqDiv.remove(); questions.style.display = ''; } headerDiv.appendChild(backButton); } function handleMutations(mutationsList, observer) { if (observerRunning) return; observerRunning = true; addHQButton(); addHeadquarterButton(); observer.observe(document.documentElement, { childList: true, subtree: true }); observerRunning = false; } const electionObserver = new MutationObserver((mutations, electionObserverInstance) => { for (let mutation of mutations) { if (mutation.type === "childList") { const electionElement = document.getElementById("election_night_buttons"); if (electionElement) { const electionPlaylist = new Playlist(); const electionSong = new Song( "Happy Survival", "Childish Gambino", "https://itsastronomical.com/assets/2024/bando.gif", "https://audio.jukehost.co.uk/KYHOjg3S1P8gsvKo3FQsDBn5PXJwFRNR" ); electionPlaylist.addSong(electionSong); changePlaylist(electionPlaylist); electionObserverInstance.disconnect(); break; } } } }); electionObserver.observe(document.body, { childList: true, subtree: true }); let observerRunning = false; var element = document.getElementById('controlElement'); if (!element) { let singleObserver = new MutationObserver(handleMutations); singleObserver.observe(document.documentElement, { childList: true, subtree: true }); var controlElement = document.createElement('div'); controlElement.style.display = 'none'; controlElement.id = 'controlElement'; document.body.appendChild(controlElement); } // hqDiv.style.height = '54%'; // hqDiv.style.height = '55%';
